title: Lifelong wheel running exercise and mild caloric restriction attenuate nuclear EndoG in the aging plantaris muscle.
summary: This study investigates how lifelong mild caloric restriction and voluntary wheel running exercise combat age-related muscle wasting (sarcopenia) in rats. The research focused on a specific type of programmed cell death known as caspase-independent apoptosis. Key findings show that aging leads to a significant increase of the pro-apoptotic protein EndoG in the muscle cell nucleus, a step linked to muscle atrophy. Both caloric restriction alone and caloric restriction combined with exercise significantly reduced this age-related accumulation of nuclear EndoG. Furthermore, the study found that aging decreased levels of the protective heat shock protein HSP27. Both interventions successfully restored HSP27 levels, with the combination of exercise and caloric restriction being particularly effective at increasing the protein's active, phosphorylated form. These results suggest that lifestyle interventions can protect aging muscle by mitigating specific apoptotic pathways, potentially through the protective signaling of HSP27.

title: Age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment are attenuated by lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise.
summary: This study investigates how lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise can combat age-related muscle loss, known as sarcopenia, by protecting the muscle cell membrane. Researchers compared young rats with old rats that were either fed normally, had their calories restricted by 8%, or had restricted calories plus access to a running wheel. The results showed that normal aging in rats disrupts key structural proteins in the muscle fiber membrane, called the dystrophin glycoprotein complex (DGC). This disruption was accompanied by a significant increase in membrane repair proteins, suggesting chronic damage, and a decrease in certain subunits of the Nox2 protein complex. However, the interventions of lifelong caloric restriction and, even more effectively, caloric restriction combined with exercise, provided significant protection against these changes. These countermeasures helped maintain the integrity of the DGC, kept repair proteins at levels closer to those of young rats, and prevented the loss of Nox2 subunits. The findings support the hypothesis that these lifestyle interventions are effective at preserving a healthy muscle membrane environment during aging.

title: The impact of SRT2104 on skeletal muscle mitochondrial function, redox biology, and loss of muscle mass in hindlimb unloaded rats.
summary: This study investigates whether the SIRT1 activator, SRT2104, can prevent skeletal muscle atrophy and mitochondrial dysfunction caused by mechanical unloading, which simulates microgravity conditions in spaceflight. Using a rat model, researchers compared three groups: a control group, a group subjected to 10 days of hindlimb unloading (HU), and a hindlimb-unloaded group treated with SRT2104. The research found that hindlimb unloading impaired mitochondrial function and caused significant muscle loss in the gastrocnemius muscle. Treatment with SRT2104 effectively preserved mitochondrial energy production capabilities, keeping them similar to the control group. Importantly, the SRT2104 treatment significantly attenuated the loss of muscle mass observed in the untreated unloaded group. While SRT2104 surprisingly increased the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), it also boosted the activity of the antioxidant enzyme superoxide dismutase. These findings suggest that SRT2104 could be a potential countermeasure to protect against muscle wasting in astronauts by maintaining mitochondrial health and function during space missions.

title: Bioreactor development for skeletal muscle hypertrophy and atrophy by manipulating uniaxial cyclic strain: Proof of concept.
summary: This research provides a proof-of-concept for a bioreactor designed to simulate the effects of mechanical loading and unloading on skeletal muscle, relevant to spaceflight. The study addresses the challenge of muscle atrophy experienced by astronauts in microgravity by creating a ground-based model. Researchers used a system to apply cyclic, uniaxial tensile strain to mouse muscle cells (myotubes) to mimic exercise and then ceased the strain to simulate the unloading conditions of space. The key finding was that applying this mechanical stretch induced myotube growth (hypertrophy), as indicated by increased cell diameter and anabolic protein markers. Conversely, stopping the stretch protocol led to significant myotube shrinkage (atrophy). This atrophy was accompanied by a decrease in growth signals and a sharp increase in catabolic and inflammatory markers, such as IL-1ß, IL-6, and NF-kappaB. The study successfully demonstrates that this bioreactor system can effectively model both muscle hypertrophy and atrophy at a cellular level, making it a promising tool for future space biology research.

title: Genomic and phenotypic characterization of Burkholderia isolates from the potable water system of the International Space Station
summary: This research paper details the microbial analysis of two flex lines from the International Space Station's (ISS) Urine Processor Assembly, part of the Water Recovery System. Scientists evaluated water samples returned to Earth and identified several bacterial and fungal species, notably Burkholderia contaminans and Paraburkholderia fungorum. The most significant finding was the first documented evidence of fungal-bacterial biofilms forming within these specific UPA flex lines. Genomic analysis of the Burkholderia isolates revealed they were unique compared to previously studied ISS water microbes, possessing distinct gene clusters for chromate resistance. These bacteria also showed genetic potential for robust biofilm formation, quorum sensing, and producing antifungal compounds. Subsequent lab tests confirmed the strong biofilm-forming capabilities of the B. contaminans isolates. Collectively, the data establishes these UPA lines as a novel ecological niche for biofilm growth. These findings will inform the design of future water systems to better prevent microbial contamination and biofouling on long-duration space missions.

title: CAMDLES: CFD-DEM Simulation of Microbial Communities in Spaceflight and Artificial Microgravity
summary: This research introduces a new computational model called CAMDLES, designed to simulate microbial communities in spaceflight and ground-based artificial microgravity devices. The model aims to understand how well these simulators, specifically rotating wall vessel bioreactors (RWVs), replicate the unique fluid environment of space. Researchers used CAMDLES to model a cooperative community of E. coli and Salmonella enterica, which depend on each other for metabolites to grow. The primary finding was that the greatest difference in growth between true microgravity and simulated microgravity (or 1 g) occurs when the bacteria form dense, co-localized aggregates. In the stillness of true microgravity, close proximity is crucial for efficient nutrient exchange and growth. The model also showed that growth is influenced by population density, spatial distribution, and metabolite diffusion rates. This simulation provides a valuable framework for generating hypotheses and designing future laboratory experiments on microbial interactions in space.

title: Hardware validation of the Advanced Plant Habitat on ISS: Canopy photosynthesis in reduced gravity.
summary: This research details the successful hardware validation of the Advanced Plant Habitat (APH), the largest plant growth facility on the International Space Station (ISS). The primary objective was to confirm that the APH is fully operational and capable of conducting complex plant research in microgravity. During a seven-week test, researchers grew Arabidopsis and wheat to assess the APH's ability to control environmental factors like light, CO2, temperature, and humidity, all commanded remotely from the ground. The experiment validated key crew procedures for planting and harvesting within the closed system. Using the wheat plants, the test confirmed the system's proficiency in managing root zone moisture and recycling transpired water. title: Trimeric structure of (+)-pinoresinol-forming dirigent protein at 1.95 A resolution with three isolated active sites.
summary: This research provides the first three-dimensional structure of a (+)-pinoresinol-forming dirigent protein (DP), PsDRR206, determined using x-ray crystallography at a high resolution of 1.95 Å. Dirigent proteins are essential in plants for guiding the specific coupling of molecules called monolignols to form lignans. The study reveals that PsDRR206 exists as a tightly packed trimer, a complex of three identical protein units. A key finding is that each unit, or monomer, contains a putative substrate-binding active site. These three active sites are positioned far apart on the trimer's surface, making interaction between them unlikely. This spatial arrangement strongly suggests that the stereoselective coupling of two monolignol radicals to form pinoresinol occurs within a single isolated active site. The structure also highlights specific amino acid residues near the active site that are believed to control whether the (+) or (−) version of the product is formed. These findings offer significant new insights into the molecular mechanisms controlling the biosynthesis of lignans and lignin in plants.

title: Reduced Arogenate Dehydratase Expression: Ramifications for Photosynthesis and Metabolism
summary: This research investigates the consequences of reducing the enzyme arogenate dehydratase (ADT) in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. ADT is essential for producing phenylalanine, a key component for lignin and many other secondary metabolites. By analyzing ADT-deficient mutants, the study found that limiting this metabolic pathway has significant downstream effects on photosynthesis. Specifically, the reduced carbon flow into phenylalanine synthesis impairs the plant's ability to consume ATP produced during photosynthesis. This leads to a metabolic backup, causing a temporary overaccumulation of starch and lower photosynthetic electron transport rates. The mechanism involves an increased proton motive force across the thylakoid membrane, which down-regulates photosystem II activity. Furthermore, the mutants showed reduced levels of various secondary compounds like flavonoids and phenylpropanoids, while other molecules such as galactolipids increased. Despite these impacts on photosynthetic efficiency, the overall net carbon fixation rate was not significantly different from the wild-type plants. The findings reveal the profound interconnection between a plant's secondary metabolism and its primary energy-capturing processes, with implications for future plant metabolic engineering.

title: New insights into lignification via network and multi-omics analyses of arogenate dehydratase knock-out mutants in Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: This research investigates the system-wide biological effects of knocking out arogenate dehydratase (ADT) genes in the model plant, *Arabidopsis thaliana*. These genetic modifications result in plants with significantly reduced lignin levels, up to a 70% reduction compared to wild-type plants. Using an integrated multi-omics approach, the study analyzed the metabolome, transcriptome, and proteome to understand the broad consequences of this genetic perturbation. The findings reveal that besides the expected decrease in phenylpropanoids like lignin, there were significant changes in other metabolic pathways, including those for glucosinolates, carotenoids, and photosynthesis. Network analysis identified novel proteins related to ribosomes and mRNA processing that were highly correlated with lignin levels. This supports a new hypothesis that lignin biosynthesis is regulated not just at the transcriptional level, but also through post-transcriptional and translational mechanisms. These insights identify new potential protein targets for future biochemical analysis and plant bioengineering.

title: Functional consequences of radiation-induced oxidative stress in cultured neural stem cells and the brain exposed to charged particle irradiation
summary: This research investigates the effects of low-dose charged particle irradiation, mimicking space radiation, on the central nervous system. The study found that even very low doses of charged particles cause acute and persistent oxidative stress in cultured neural stem cells. This oxidative stress can last for weeks to months after the initial exposure. Experiments with mice showed that whole-body irradiation initially triggered a compensatory increase in the brain's antioxidant capacity, which later returned to normal levels. Critically, mice exposed to this low-dose radiation exhibited significant cognitive impairment, specifically in novel object recognition, at both 2 and 12 weeks post-irradiation. These findings provide evidence that exposure to space-relevant radiation can elicit long-lasting cellular stress associated with functional cognitive deficits. The study concludes that astronauts may be at a heightened risk for performance decrements during missions and could develop long-term neurocognitive issues due to space radiation exposure.

title: Exploration of space to achieve scientific breakthroughs
summary: This research analyzes the current state of beta cell replacement therapy for type 1 diabetes (T1D), highlighting major breakthroughs using stem cell-derived cells. While initial clinical trials have successfully demonstrated insulin production in patients, the paper argues that significant challenges remain in making the therapy widely accessible. Using space exploration as an analogy, it compares the current stage to landing on the moon—a remarkable scientific feat, but far from the goal of broad colonization. The author warns that without a strategic shift, these treatments risk becoming too expensive and complex for widespread use, similar to other advanced therapies that have failed commercially. To address this, the paper proposes adopting a 'Quality by Design' (QbD) framework. This approach prioritizes scalability, ease of administration, and economic feasibility from the earliest stages of research. The central argument is that the field must move beyond proving scientific concepts and focus on designing a practical, affordable, and scalable solution to truly provide a cure for millions of patients.

title: Network Analysis of Gene Transcriptions of Arabidopsis thaliana in Spaceflight Microgravity.
summary: This research analyzes how spaceflight microgravity affects gene expression related to root growth in the plant model organism Arabidopsis thaliana. Using transcriptomic data from plants grown on the International Space Station, scientists employed computational tools to create gene regulatory networks. These networks identified key 'hub genes' that respond differently in space compared to on the ground. The study found that hub genes significantly altered by microgravity are mainly involved in cell wall synthesis, protein transport, stress responses, and response to auxin. Specifically, the analysis highlighted five important root growth-regulating hub genes that have the highest influence in spaceflight conditions. Furthermore, the research uncovered genes involved in cell wall biosynthesis that show higher transcriptional regulation in microgravity. The study compared different ecotypes (WS, Col-0) and a mutant (phyD), revealing distinct genetic responses to the space environment. These findings are crucial for understanding how plants adapt to spaceflight at a molecular level.

title: Detection of Genes in Arabidopsis thaliana L. Responding to DNA Damage from Radiation and Other Stressors in Spaceflight
summary: This research analyzes the genetic responses of the plant Arabidopsis thaliana to DNA damage from ionizing radiation in spaceflight conditions. Using computational methods to analyze gene expression data from GeneLab, the study infers gene regulatory networks to identify key biological processes and genes. A primary finding is that the plant's DNA damage response involves not only radiation-induced genes but also non-radiation-induced genes, which link the response to other stressors like heat, salt, and water. The analysis identified several key genes, such as AT3G27060 and AT1G07500, as critical players in DNA repair. Furthermore, the study connects the DNA damage response to fundamental processes like root growth and overall plant development. It was observed that high-energy radiation elicits a more intense DNA damage response than lower doses. The research also found that protective pigments like flavonoids and carotenoids are activated in low-radiation environments but not under very high radiation exposure, suggesting complex, dose-dependent survival mechanisms.

title: The Effect of spaceflight on mouse olfactory bulb volume, neurogenesis, and cell death indicates the protective effect of novel environment.
summary: This research investigated the impact of a 13-day space mission on the olfactory bulb (OB), a key brain region for smell, in mice. The study compared mice that flew on the Space Shuttle with two ground-based control groups: one in identical specialized cages (AEM-Ground) and another in standard housing (Vivarium). Interestingly, the AEM-Ground mice showed beneficial changes, including increased OB volume, more new neurons (neurogenesis), and less cell death compared to the Vivarium mice. This suggests the specialized AEM housing acted as an enriched environment, positively stimulating the brain. However, these positive effects were completely absent in the mice that actually flew in space. The spaceflight mice had smaller OB volumes and fewer new neurons than their ground-based AEM counterparts, with levels similar to the standard Vivarium group. Furthermore, the flight mice showed an increased density of dying cells in their OB compared to the AEM-Ground group. The findings indicate that while an enriched environment can be beneficial for brain structure, the stressors of spaceflight negate these advantages and may even be detrimental. These results highlight the complex and potentially opposing effects of the space environment on the central nervous system.

title: Effects of low-dose rate Œ≥-irradiation combined with simulated microgravity on markers of oxidative stress, DNA methylation potential, and remodeling in the mouse heart
summary: This research investigated the short- and long-term cardiac effects of simulated microgravity and low-dose γ-irradiation, both separately and combined, using a mouse model to simulate space travel conditions. Researchers exposed female mice to hindlimb unloading (HU), low-dose radiation, or both for 21 days and then analyzed heart tissue at various time points up to 9 months post-exposure. The key finding was that the combination of HU and radiation caused the most significant increase in markers of oxidative stress and reduced potential for DNA methylation in the short term, specifically 7 days and 1 month after treatment. However, other indicators of cardiac remodeling and severe oxidative stress did not show significant changes. Over the long term, the study found that most of these effects were not permanent. By the 9-month follow-up, the mouse hearts appeared to have mostly recovered from the insults. The authors conclude that while there are measurable short-term cardiac effects from these combined spaceflight stressors, they may be transient, though more research with larger animal groups is necessary to confirm these findings.

title: Characterization of mouse ocular response to a 35-day spaceflight mission: Evidence of blood-retinal barrier disruption and ocular adaptations.
summary: This research investigates the effects of a 35-day spaceflight mission on the ocular health of mice, focusing on the retina and the blood-retinal barrier (BRB). Mice flown to the International Space Station were compared to ground-based control groups upon their return. The study found that spaceflight induced significant apoptosis, or programmed cell death, in the retinal cells of the flight group. Key findings indicate a disruption of the BRB, supported by increased expression of proteins like AQP-4 and PECAM-1 and decreased expression of the tight junction protein ZO-1. A comprehensive proteomic analysis revealed that spaceflight significantly altered numerous proteins and cellular pathways responsible for cell death, immune response, and mitochondrial function. Interestingly, post-flight intraocular pressure was found to be lower in the flight group's left eye, though the biological significance of this is considered uncertain. These results suggest that long-duration spaceflight triggers a complex cellular stress response that can alter the structure of the retina and compromise the integrity of the blood-retinal barrier.

title: Mice Exposed to Combined Chronic Low-Dose Irradiation and Modeled Microgravity Develop Long-Term Neurological Sequelae.
summary: This study investigates the long-term neurological consequences of simulated spaceflight conditions on mice. Researchers exposed mice to simulated microgravity (hindlimb unloading, HLU), chronic low-dose radiation (LDR), or a combination of both for 21 days, followed by a four-month recovery period. After this readaptation phase, they analyzed gene expression and epigenetic changes in the animals' brains. The findings revealed that mice exposed to either HLU or LDR individually showed only minimal and minor long-term alterations. In contrast, mice subjected to the combined HLU and LDR treatment displayed significant and numerous changes in gene expression. These changes affected critical pathways involved in neurogenesis, neuroplasticity, neuropeptide regulation, and cellular signaling. The study concludes that the combined stressors of microgravity and radiation have a synergistic effect, posing a greater long-term risk to the central nervous system than either factor alone, potentially leading to late-onset neurological problems.

title: Spaceflight influences gene expression, photoreceptor integrity, and oxidative stress-related damage in the murine retina.
summary: This study investigates the molecular and structural impact of extended spaceflight on the retinas of mice. Researchers compared mice that spent 35 days aboard the International Space Station (ISS) with a ground control group to understand the causes of vision problems in astronauts. RNA sequencing of the spaceflight mice revealed changes in the expression of 600 genes, many of which are critical for visual perception and converting light into neural signals. Notably, twelve of these altered genes are also associated with the degenerative eye disease retinitis pigmentosa. The study also found significant physical damage, including the degradation of cone photoreceptors and increased markers of oxidative stress. Furthermore, imaging showed a significant thinning of the retina, retinal pigment epithelium, and choroid layers. These results strongly suggest that the spaceflight environment induces retinal injury through oxidative damage and altered gene regulation, which may lead to progressive visual impairment on long-duration missions.

title: Evaluating ocular response in the retina and optic nerve head after single and fractionated high-energy protons
summary: This study investigates the long-term ocular damage caused by space-relevant proton radiation, using mice as a model. Researchers exposed mice to a low dose of high-energy protons, delivered either all at once or in smaller, fractionated doses over several weeks to simulate chronic exposure. Four months after irradiation, the study found significant damage to the retina and optic nerve head. Key findings include increased rates of cell death (apoptosis) and heightened oxidative stress in the ocular tissues of irradiated mice. The single, acute radiation dose produced more pronounced oxidative stress compared to the fractionated doses. Furthermore, the integrity of the blood-retina barrier was compromised, indicated by changes in the expression of key regulatory proteins. The study demonstrates that even low doses of proton radiation can lead to lasting damage and that different parts of the eye, like the retina and optic nerve head, may respond differently to various radiation exposure schedules. These results highlight potential health risks for astronauts on long-duration space missions.

title: Characterization of gene expression profiles in the mouse brain after 35 days of spaceflight mission.
summary: This research investigates the impact of a 35-day spaceflight mission on the brains of mice by analyzing gene expression profiles. Upon returning to Earth, brain tissue analysis revealed significant changes in 54 genes compared to a ground control group. The study found that spaceflight altered numerous biological pathways, including those for cellular stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and metabolism. A key finding was the decreased expression of genes crucial for neuronal function, oligodendrocyte differentiation, and the maintenance of the myelin sheath. Furthermore, genes related to the innate immune system, such as those for anti-viral signaling and bacterial immune response, were significantly downregulated. In contrast, genes associated with cellular stress and DNA damage were upregulated. The authors conclude that spaceflight-induced stress leads to altered immune reactions in the brain, which in turn has a negative impact on overall neuronal function.

title: A multi-omics longitudinal study of the murine retinal response to chronic low-dose irradiation and simulated microgravity.
summary: This study investigates the long-term effects of simulated microgravity and chronic low-dose radiation, both individually and combined, on the retina of mice. Using a multi-omics approach, researchers analyzed changes in gene expression and DNA methylation at 7 days, 1 month, and 4 months after a 21-day exposure period. The analysis identified 4,178 differentially methylated sites and 457 differentially expressed genes, revealing that the biological response was highly time-dependent. Key findings showed that nucleotide metabolism was consistently altered across all groups, being activated at 1 month but suppressed at other time points. At 4 months post-exposure, important developmental signaling pathways like Notch and Wnt showed significant alterations, primarily through changes in DNA methylation. The study also identified 23 specific genes involved in retinal function and inflammation that had significant changes in both their expression and methylation. This research provides critical insight into the distinct and synergistic molecular impacts of spaceflight hazards on the retina, highlighting persistent changes relevant for astronaut health.

title: Evidence of spaceflight-induced adverse effects on photoreceptors and retinal function in the mouse eye.
summary: This study investigated the effects of a 35-day space mission on the eyes of mice flown aboard the International Space Station. Researchers aimed to characterize damage to the retina and test the effectiveness of an antioxidant treatment called BuOE. The key finding was that spaceflight induced significant oxidative stress and increased programmed cell death (apoptosis) within the mouse retina. This cellular damage resulted in a measurable decline in retinal function, confirmed by significantly reduced electrical responses from photoreceptor cells (a- and b-waves in electroretinogram tests). The antioxidant treatment successfully lowered the biomarkers for oxidative stress. However, it had a limited effect on preventing cell death or restoring the impaired retinal function. These results provide the first evidence linking spaceflight conditions to functional damage in photoreceptors. The study concludes that while oxidative stress is a key factor, other mechanisms may also contribute to retinal damage during spaceflight.

title: Effects of spaceflight on the brain
summary: This study investigates how changes in gravity affect human position sense, also known as proprioception, during parabolic flights. Researchers tested participants under conditions of normal gravity (1G), hypergravity (1.8G), and microgravity (0G) using three different measurement tasks: two-arm matching, one-arm pointing, and one-arm repositioning. The key finding is that the effect of gravity on position sense is dependent on the measurement method used. For the matching and pointing tasks, errors increased significantly in hypergravity. In microgravity, matching errors decreased significantly, while the decrease in pointing errors was not significant. In stark contrast, the repositioning task showed no significant changes in performance under altered gravity conditions. The authors propose that the errors in matching and pointing are caused by gravity's force acting on muscle and joint receptors. title: Routine omics collection is a golden opportunity for European human research in space and analog environments.
summary: This paper advocates for establishing a routine 'omics' data collection program for European astronauts and commercial spaceflight participants. The research proposes that the widespread generation of data, such as genomics and proteomics, is now technologically feasible and presents a golden opportunity to advance space medicine. A key finding is that a standardized, longitudinal data resource would provide deep mechanistic insights into spaceflight-induced health issues. This would improve occupational healthcare, enable personalized medicine, and reduce risks for future long-duration missions to the Moon and Mars. The authors consider the practicalities of such a program, including which samples to collect and when. The paper also thoroughly appraises the significant ethical and legal challenges, particularly regarding European data privacy laws like GDPR. Ultimately, creating this AI-ready dataset is crucial for unlocking powerful new analytical approaches to ensure astronaut health and mission success.

title: Spatial omics technologies at multimodal and single cell/subcellular level.
summary: Spatial omics technologies are powerful methods for understanding how cells are organized and interact within their native tissue context. This research paper provides a comprehensive review of current and emerging technologies that can map the location of transcripts and proteins at single-cell and even subcellular resolutions. The authors categorize these techniques into two main groups: targeted methods that use probes or antibodies for specific molecules, and unbiased transcriptome-wide methods based on next-generation sequencing. A variety of platforms are discussed, highlighting their differing capabilities in resolution, scale, and multiplexing capacity. The paper outlines the typical experimental workflow, from sample preparation using frozen or fixed tissues to complex data analysis. It emphasizes that the choice of technology depends on the specific research question, involving trade-offs between targeted depth and discovery-based breadth. Ultimately, these rapidly advancing tools are enabling a deeper, multi-modal understanding of cellular biology for both research and clinical applications.

title: Genomic characterization and radiation tolerance of Naganishia kalamii sp. nov. and Cystobasidium onofrii sp. nov. from Mars 2020 mission assembly facilities.
summary: Researchers discovered two new species of yeast in NASA cleanrooms used for assembling the Mars 2020 mission spacecraft. Using a combination of morphological analysis and advanced genomic sequencing, they identified and characterized these previously unknown fungi. The new species were named Naganishia kalamii, found at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, and Cystobasidium onofrii, found at the Kennedy Space Center. Genomic analysis revealed that both yeasts possess genes associated with resistance to extreme conditions such as dehydration, desiccation, and cold. Experiments confirmed their extremotolerant nature, showing both species are highly resistant to UV-C radiation. These findings are significant for planetary protection, as the survival of such hardy microbes in sterile environments poses a risk for forward contamination of other planets. The study highlights the need to better understand and develop countermeasures against extremophilic fungi to ensure the biological integrity of space missions.

title: Genome and clonal hematopoiesis stability contrasts with immune, cfDNA, mitochondrial, and telomere length changes during short duration spaceflight
summary: This study investigates the physiological and genetic effects of short-duration spaceflight on the four civilian crew members of the Inspiration4 mission. Researchers analyzed blood samples collected before, during, and after the three-day orbital flight. The key findings reveal that while the crew's telomeres elongated in space and shortened upon returning to Earth, their overall genomes remained stable. There were no significant observations of whole-genome instability or clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP), a condition linked to age-related diseases. However, analysis of cell-free DNA (cfDNA) and gene expression showed significant changes in the immune system. Specifically, there were increased signatures of immune cell activity post-flight, with some cellular adaptations persisting for months after the mission. The research concludes that even brief space travel induces dynamic biological changes, particularly in telomere length and immune response, while the genome remains largely stable. These findings provide a valuable baseline for future commercial and deep-space exploration missions.

title: Inspiration4 data access through the NASA Open Science Data Repository
summary: This paper serves as a guide to the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR), which provides open and FAIR access to biological data from the SpaceX Inspiration4 (I4) mission. The I4 mission collected an extensive and unprecedented dataset, including omics and clinical assays, from four civilian astronauts to understand the impact of commercial space travel on human health. This repository allows researchers to conduct multi-modal, longitudinal assessments of the physiological responses to short-duration spaceflight. The data is standardized and structured for advanced analysis using artificial intelligence and machine learning to uncover new insights. The article details how to access and analyze these valuable datasets through the OSDR portal and programmatically using the GLOpenAPI. This pioneering effort aims to accelerate research into space health, guide future mission planning, and establish a new precedent for post-mission health monitoring programs.

title: Molecular and physiologic changes in the SpaceX Inspiration4 civilian crew
summary: This research analyzes the molecular and physiological changes experienced by the first all-civilian crew during the 3-day SpaceX Inspiration4 mission. Researchers collected a wide range of biomedical data using multi-omic profiling, handheld ultrasound imaging, wearable sensors, and cognitive tests before, during, and after the flight. The study found that the short-duration spaceflight induced a broad set of temporary changes, including physiological stress, neurovestibular alterations, and telomere elongation, some of which mirrored effects seen in long-duration missions. A key finding was that nearly all of these biological changes returned to pre-flight baseline levels shortly after the crew returned to Earth. The data suggests that short-duration missions do not pose a significant health risk to civilian astronauts. This mission also successfully demonstrated the feasibility of collecting complex biomedical data from a non-professional crew. The results provide a valuable look at the earliest phases of human adaptation to spaceflight and contribute to a growing biomedical database for future missions.

title: Telomeric RNA (TERRA) increases in response to spaceflight and high-altitude climbing
summary: This research investigates the role of telomeric RNA (TERRA) in response to environmental stressors like spaceflight and high-altitude climbing. The study found significantly increased levels of TERRA in astronauts during space missions and in mountaineers climbing Mt. Everest. Through cellular models, the researchers determined that this increase is a direct response to radiation-induced DNA damage, specifically double-strand breaks (DSBs) at the telomeres, and not due to microgravity. In response to this damage, TERRA transcription is upregulated, and it binds to the damaged telomeric DNA, forming protective hybrid structures. This mechanism is characteristic of the Alternative Lengthening of Telomeres (ALT) pathway, a telomere repair system typically found in cancer cells. The findings suggest that chronic radiation exposure can transiently activate this ALT pathway in normal human cells as a protective measure. These results have important implications for understanding cellular aging and the health risks associated with chronic radiation exposure.

title: Spatial multi-omics of human skin reveals KRAS and inflammatory responses to spaceflight
summary: This study investigates the molecular changes in human skin caused by short-duration spaceflight. Researchers performed a multi-omics analysis on skin biopsies from the four Inspiration4 crew members before and after their three-day mission. The key findings show that spaceflight significantly increased the expression of genes related to inflammation and KRAS signaling across all layers of the skin. This response included DNA damage, disruption of the skin's protective barrier, altered immune responses, and hindered regeneration, particularly in the outer skin compartments. The study also linked these epithelial disruptions to shifts in the skin's microbial communities and correlated local immune changes with systemic responses seen in the crew's blood cells. This research represents the first spatial analysis of astronaut skin, providing a detailed map of gene expression changes. The findings offer crucial insights for developing countermeasures to protect astronaut skin health on future missions.

title: Longitudinal multi-omics analysis of host microbiome architecture and immune responses during short-term spaceflight
summary: This research investigates the impact of a three-day spaceflight on the microbiome and immune systems of four civilian astronauts. Through a six-month study involving over 750 samples from 10 body sites, scientists characterized microbial changes before, during, and after the mission. The key finding is that most microbiome alterations were transient, reverting to normal after returning to Earth. For instance, viruses on the skin temporarily increased during flight. However, the study identified longer-term shifts in the oral microbiome, including a persistent increase in plaque-associated bacteria like Fusobacteriota. These oral changes were found to correlate with changes in the gene expression of the astronauts' immune cells. Additionally, microbial genes related to stress, phage activity, and toxin-antitoxin systems were enriched across multiple body sites during spaceflight. The findings provide an in-depth characterization of how short-term space travel affects the human microbiome and immune system, informing health monitoring strategies for future missions.

title: Spatiotemporal expression and control of haemoglobin in space
summary: This study analyzes how spaceflight affects haemoglobin and red blood cell production by examining multi-omic data from the NASA Twins, JAXA CFE, and Inspiration4 missions. Researchers investigated gene expression changes in astronauts before, during, and after their time in space. The key finding is that spaceflight causes a significant down-regulation of adult globin genes, leading to a condition known as "space anaemia," where red blood cell mass is reduced. Upon returning to Earth, these gene expression levels recover and even increase. The study also discovered the activation of an "adult-to-fetal" globin gene switch, where genes normally active during fetal development are turned on in response to the space environment. This indicates that microgravity elicits complex regulatory changes in the body's process of creating new red blood cells (erythropoiesis). These findings provide valuable insights into the dynamic physiological adaptations of the human body to space.

title: Single-cell multi-ome and immune profiles of the Inspiration4 crew reveal conserved, cell-type, and sex-specific responses to spaceflight
summary: This study analyzes the immune system responses of the four-person SpaceX Inspiration4 crew to a three-day orbital spaceflight. Using advanced single-cell and multi-omic profiling of blood samples, researchers identified significant changes in 18 cytokines and chemokines related to inflammation, aging, and muscle function upon return to Earth. They discovered a core "spaceflight signature" in gene expression, impacting pathways like oxidative phosphorylation and UV response, which was conserved when compared to data from the NASA Twins Study and mouse experiments. Different immune cells exhibited unique responses, with monocytes showing the most pronounced and slowest-recovering changes. Notably, the study found a long-term suppression of MHC class I genes, which are crucial for fighting infections. Furthermore, comparisons with lab-simulated microgravity suggest that these gene expression changes are likely driven more by radiation and other spaceflight stressors than by microgravity alone. These detailed findings provide a crucial roadmap for developing countermeasures to preserve astronaut health on future missions.

title: Single-cell analysis identifies conserved features of immune dysfunction in simulated microgravity and spaceflight
summary: This research investigates how microgravity causes immune system dysfunction at the cellular level. Using single-cell analysis on human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) in simulated microgravity, the study identifies specific genes and pathways that are altered. The findings show that microgravity impairs the function of T cells and NK cells while increasing inflammatory activity in monocytes. These changes were validated against data from actual spaceflight missions, including the Inspiration-4 and Twins studies. Researchers observed that microgravity reduces interferon signaling while increasing pathways related to inflammation, stress, and the cytoskeleton. This environment also appears to induce an inflammatory state similar to aging and can trigger the transcription of latent viruses and bacteria. Using machine learning, the study identified the plant-based compound quercetin as a potential countermeasure capable of reversing most of the observed negative immune changes. These results define the core cellular alterations to immunity in space and offer a promising direction for protecting astronaut health.

title: The Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) and international astronaut biobank
summary: This research introduces the Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA), a comprehensive data and sample repository for biological research on astronauts. SOMA significantly expands publicly available human space omics data by more than tenfold, integrating genomics, proteomics, metabolomics, and microbiome profiles from diverse missions like the SpaceX Inspiration4. The primary goal is to accelerate the development of precision aerospace medicine to better monitor and mitigate the health risks of space travel. A key finding from the analysis of the short 3-day Inspiration4 mission was the rapid onset of physiological changes, such as telomere elongation, which was previously observed only in long-duration missions. The study confirmed consistent immune responses, including specific cytokine shifts, seen in other astronaut cohorts. Additionally, novel techniques like spatial transcriptomics of skin and cell-free RNA (cfRNA) profiling were used to identify unique molecular fingerprints of spaceflight. These new datasets revealed adaptive skin responses and systemic changes involving multiple cell types, providing an unprecedented resource for future deep-space exploration missions.

title: Secretome profiling reveals acute changes in oxidative stress, brain homeostasis, and coagulation following short-duration spaceflight
summary: This study analyzed blood samples from the four civilian astronauts of the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission to understand the physiological impacts of short-duration spaceflight. Researchers profiled the "spaceflight secretome," examining proteins and metabolites in plasma and extracellular vesicles before and after the three-day trip. The findings revealed significant acute changes related to oxidative stress, blood coagulation, and brain health. While most metabolic and vesicle protein changes were temporary, returning to normal within months, a majority of the altered plasma proteins remained perturbed long after the flight. The research suggests that immune cells are a primary source of these persistent protein changes. Furthermore, the detection of brain-enriched proteins in blood, along with supporting data from spaceflight mice, indicates a potential disruption of the blood-brain barrier. These results highlight that even brief space travel can cause profound physiological disruptions, identifying important biomarkers for future astronaut health monitoring.

title: Astronaut omics and the impact of space on the human body at scale
summary: This paper proposes the creation of a 'Human Cell Space Atlas' as a global, open-access resource for space life science research. This initiative would parallel the terrestrial Human Cell Atlas, using high-resolution omics data to map human cellular responses to the spaceflight environment. The ultimate goal is to enable precision spaceflight healthcare, tailoring nutrition, pharmaceuticals, and countermeasures to individual astronauts for future long-duration missions to Mars. The research highlights that individual genetic variations significantly impact the metabolism of drugs, micronutrients, and macronutrients in space. For example, specific genetic polymorphisms can alter an astronaut's response to common sleep medications or influence their susceptibility to space-related health issues like Spaceflight-Associated Neuro-Ocular Syndrome (SANS). The authors stress the critical need for international collaboration and standardized data collection protocols to overcome the challenge of small sample sizes. They also acknowledge the complex ethical, cultural, and legal considerations that must be addressed in the field of human space omics.

title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations underpinning spaceflight dermatology.
summary: This research investigates the underlying molecular causes of skin problems, which are frequently reported by astronauts during spaceflight. Using a systems biology approach, the study analyzed gene expression data from space-flown mice and human astronauts from various missions, including the NASA Twins Study and the commercial Inspiration4 mission. The analysis identified key biological changes that are potential drivers for dermatological issues in space. These changes include alterations in genes related to DNA damage and repair, mitochondrial dysregulation, skin barrier function, and collagen formation. A machine learning model was also used to identify synergistic gene pairings associated with the skin's response to spaceflight. While significant dysregulation was observed during missions, the findings also highlight the body's remarkable ability to re-adapt post-flight, with gene expression re-tuning upon return to Earth. These insights are crucial for developing future countermeasures to protect astronaut skin health on long-duration missions.

title: Cosmic kidney disease: an integrated pan-omic, physiological and morphological study into spaceflight-induced renal dysfunction
summary: This comprehensive study investigates the largely unknown effects of long-duration spaceflight on kidney health, analyzing samples from human and rodent space missions and simulations. Using a wide array of biomolecular, chemical, and imaging techniques, researchers uncovered three key findings. First, spaceflight alters the function of renal transporters, suggesting that the increased risk of kidney stones in astronauts is a direct kidney issue, not just a secondary effect of bone loss. Second, the study revealed significant structural remodeling within the kidney's nephrons, where tubules decrease in overall density but expand in individual size. Third, exposure to simulated galactic cosmic radiation, equivalent to a roundtrip mission to Mars, was shown to cause tangible kidney damage and early signs of dysfunction. These results highlight previously unappreciated risks to renal health during deep space exploration. The research provides a crucial foundation for understanding and mitigating potential health issues for future astronauts.

title: Spaceflight induces changes in gene expression profiles linked to insulin and estrogen
summary: This research investigates how spaceflight alters energy metabolism and sex hormone signaling at a molecular level in both mice and humans. By analyzing gene expression and protein data from rodents on the International Space Station and human spaceflight participants, the study identified significant changes in pathways related to insulin and estrogen. In mice, the most pronounced effects were observed in the liver, where spaceflight inhibited insulin and estrogen signaling, leading to hepatic insulin resistance and steatosis (fatty liver). Different muscle tissues also exhibited varied metabolic responses depending on their specific functions. Similarly, in humans, spaceflight induced changes in genes associated with insulin resistance and estrogen signaling pathways. title: Protective alleles and precision healthcare in crewed spaceflight
summary: This research explores the application of human genetics and omics technologies to enhance healthcare for astronauts during deep space missions. The authors review existing literature on naturally occurring genetic variants (alleles) that offer protective effects against significant spaceflight health risks. Key concerns addressed include radiation-induced cancer and bone demineralization caused by microgravity. The paper highlights specific alleles discovered in unique human cohorts that are linked to benefits like increased muscle mass, stronger bones, and improved cardiovascular health. By studying the mechanisms of these protective genes, researchers aim to develop personalized countermeasures. These countermeasures could include tailored nutrition, exercise programs, and health recommendations to better protect crew members. While acknowledging technical and ethical challenges, the findings could also benefit terrestrial populations facing similar health issues, such as the elderly or radiation workers. The paper advocates for integrating precision medicine into aerospace healthcare to support a more diverse generation of space explorers.

title: Growth chambers on the International Space Station for large plants
summary: This research investigates how growing wheat in the microgravity environment of the International Space Station (ISS) affects its grain quality. Scientists compared 'Super Dwarf' wheat kernels grown in the Lada growth chamber on the ISS to a control group grown in an identical chamber on Earth. The study found that wheat kernels from the ISS were slightly but significantly smaller in weight, area, length, and width. Contrary to the initial hypothesis, space-grown kernels did not exhibit increased physical asymmetry compared to their terrestrial counterparts, with both groups showing low asymmetry levels. Analysis of the internal structure revealed that the ratio of type B to type A starch granules was lower in the space-grown wheat. Additionally, the aleurone layer cells in mature ISS kernels were significantly narrower than the control group. These findings suggest that the baking qualities of Earth-grown kernels might be slightly superior. The work also proposes a novel, non-destructive method for assessing kernel asymmetry for future in-orbit analysis.

title: Microbiological and nutritional analysis of lettuce crops grown on the International Space Station
summary: This study investigates the safety and nutritional quality of red romaine lettuce grown aboard the International Space Station (ISS) to supplement astronaut diets. Researchers cultivated lettuce in 'Veggie' growth chambers on the ISS and compared it to control plants grown on Earth under simulated space conditions. The analysis focused on the lettuce's microbiological communities and nutritional composition. Key findings show that the space-grown lettuce was safe for consumption, with no human pathogens detected. While there were some differences in the total bacterial and fungal counts between space-grown and ground-grown lettuce, they were within acceptable ranges for fresh produce. The study also noted differences in microbial diversity between the leaves and roots. Nutritionally, the elemental composition of space lettuce differed in some elements like iron and potassium, but its antioxidant capacity was similar to the ground controls. The research concludes that growing safe, edible, and fresh food in space is feasible, providing valuable data for future long-duration missions.

title: Natural variation in the expression of ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 affects root length responses to cadaverine in Arabidopsis.
summary: This research investigates how the polyamine cadaverine, an organic cation, affects plant root development, a process which is not well understood. The study utilized the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana and observed that different natural strains, or accessions, exhibit varying levels of root growth sensitivity when exposed to cadaverine. Specifically, the Cape Verde Islands (Cvi) accession was found to be highly resistant to cadaverine's root-shortening effects, whereas the Landsberg erecta (Ler) accession was one of the most sensitive. Through genetic mapping, the researchers identified the gene ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 (OCT1) as being responsible for this natural variation. The key finding is that the level of OCT1 expression, rather than differences in the protein sequence itself, dictates the plant's sensitivity to cadaverine. The resistant Cvi strain showed significantly higher expression of OCT1 compared to the sensitive Ler strain. This conclusion was further supported by experiments showing that mutants without a functional OCT1 gene were more sensitive to cadaverine. Ultimately, the study demonstrates that lower expression of the OCT1 transporter confers increased sensitivity to cadaverine's impact on root growth.

title: Auxin: Shape matters.
summary: This research investigates the effects of the commercial herbicide AsiMax 50®, containing the active ingredient 2,4-D, on freshwater microbial communities. The study utilized laboratory microcosms with water from two distinct systems: a clear system and a turbid one. Researchers observed that the herbicide's impact was significantly greater in the turbid water. A key finding was the dose-dependent response; low concentrations of 2,4-D stimulated the growth of micro and nano phytoplankton in the turbid system, suggesting the herbicide mimics a natural growth hormone (auxin). Conversely, high concentrations of the herbicide decreased species richness and abundance in both clear and turbid environments. Different phytoplankton species, such as Ochromonas sp. and Chlamydomonas sp., exhibited varied responses depending on the water system they inhabited. The study concludes that environmental factors like turbidity are critical in predicting the ecotoxicological effects of herbicides on aquatic ecosystems. The authors caution that these laboratory-based findings require care when being extrapolated to real-world scenarios.

title: Gravity signaling in flowering plant roots
summary: This research investigates how rice roots respond to gravity by studying a mutant plant whose roots coil when grown in water but grow normally in soil. The study identifies that the mutation affects the CRW1 gene, which normally functions to suppress ethylene hormone signaling. In the mutant, this signaling becomes overactive, leading to an excess of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the root tip. This damages the root cap, disrupts the transport of the growth hormone auxin, and ultimately impairs the root's ability to grow downwards in response to gravity. When the roots grow in soil, the gentle mechanical resistance activates a mechanosensing pathway that involves calcium signaling. This counteracts the excessive ethylene signaling, allowing the roots to resume their normal gravitropic growth. The research uncovers a novel interplay between ethylene, mechanosensing, and auxin in controlling plant gravitropism.

title: Cadaverine regulates biotin synthesis to modulate primary root growth in Arabidopsis
summary: This research investigates how the polyamine cadaverine regulates primary root growth in the plant model Arabidopsis thaliana. Through a genetic screen, the study identified a mutant, named cdh3, which exhibits hypersensitivity to the root-growth-inhibiting effects of cadaverine. The researchers determined that this mutation is located in the BIO3-BIO1 gene, a bifunctional enzyme critical for biotin (vitamin B7) biosynthesis. An in-vitro enzyme assay confirmed that cadaverine directly inhibits the activity of the BIO3-BIO1 protein. This inhibition of biotin synthesis was shown to have downstream consequences, such as reducing the biotinylation of a key enzyme in fatty acid production and decreasing the accumulation of triacylglycerides. The study also found that supplying exogenous biotin or a specific pathway intermediate could rescue the root growth defects caused by cadaverine. These findings reveal a previously unknown mechanism where cadaverine modulates plant root architecture by acting as a natural inhibitor of the biotin synthesis pathway.

title: Low-speed clinorotation of Brachypodium distachyon and Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings triggers root tip curvatures that are reminiscent of gravitropism.
summary: This research investigates whether low-speed clinorotation, a technique used to simulate microgravity by rotating samples, itself triggers directional growth in plant roots. Using Arabidopsis thaliana and Brachypodium distachyon seedlings, the study found that slow rotation indeed causes root tips to curve. This curvature is directly linked to gravitropism, the plant's natural response to gravity, which acts during the first half-turn of the rotation. The direction and angle of the curve are dependent on the direction and speed of the clinostat's rotation. To confirm this, the researchers showed that Arabidopsis mutants with defects in gravity sensing or signal transduction did not exhibit the same curving response. The study also demonstrated that clinorotation causes a redistribution of the auxin hormone and the PIN3 protein in root tip cells, which are key molecular events in the gravitropic pathway. These findings support that the 'clinostat effect' is a gravitropic response, suggesting that low-speed clinostats may not be perfect mimics of microgravity.

title: New device for high-throughput viability screening of flow biofilms
summary: This research paper introduces a novel high-throughput method for rapidly screening the viability of bacterial biofilms grown under continuous fluid flow. Existing methods were not suitable for rapid screening of these "flow biofilms," which more accurately represent natural conditions than static ones. The new technique uses a microfluidic device, the BioFlux system, capable of cultivating 96 individual biofilms in parallel with precise flow control. Viability is assessed by measuring the fluorescence of bacteria engineered to express Green Fluorescent Protein (GFP) and stained with propidium iodide (PI), which marks dead cells. A standard plate reader quickly measures the green-to-red fluorescence ratio to determine the percentage of living cells. The study validates this method by showing strong agreement with traditional colony counting and fluorescence microscopy results. The researchers also demonstrate that their GFP-PI method is more accurate than the commonly used LIVE/DEAD BacLight stain, particularly at low antimicrobial concentrations. This new system provides a powerful tool for rapidly testing the effectiveness of antimicrobial compounds against medically and environmentally significant biofilms.

title: Sigma S-dependent antioxidant defense protects stationary-phase Escherichia coli against the bactericidal antibiotic gentamicin
summary: This research investigates how the general stress response regulator, σs (sigma S), protects stationary-phase Escherichia coli bacteria from the antibiotic gentamicin. The study found that E. coli mutants lacking the σs gene were significantly more sensitive to gentamicin than their normal counterparts. Through proteomic and chemical analyses, researchers determined that this increased sensitivity was due to a weakened antioxidant defense system in the mutants. Gentamicin treatment generated higher levels of harmful reactive oxygen species (ROS), causing greater oxidative stress in the bacteria without σs. This mechanism was confirmed by experiments showing that adding an antioxidant or creating oxygen-free conditions reduced the antibiotic's lethality. The findings were also validated in vivo using a mouse infection model. The study concludes that gentamicin's bactericidal action in stationary-phase bacteria is partly driven by inducing oxidative stress. Therefore, targeting the antioxidant defenses of bacteria could be a promising strategy to enhance the efficacy of existing antibiotics and combat resistance.

title: Plasma membrane disruption (PMD) formation and repair in mechanosensitive tissues
summary: This review examines plasma membrane disruptions (PMD), which are small, temporary tears in cell membranes caused by mechanical forces like fluid shear or physical deformation. These disruptions function as a key mechanism for mechanosensation, allowing cells in various tissues to detect and respond to their physical environment. The formation of a PMD permits an influx of extracellular calcium, which is critical for initiating cellular signaling cascades and promoting tissue adaptation. Repair of these disruptions is essential for cell survival and involves a complex, active process dependent on calcium signaling, vesicle fusion, and an array of proteins including annexins and calpains. PMD have been observed in a wide range of mechanosensitive cells, including muscle, bone, neurons, and epithelial cells. The paper compares the repair mechanisms and downstream signaling across these different cell types, with a specific focus on skeletal mechanobiology. It also explores how defects in PMD formation or repair are implicated in diseases such as muscular dystrophy, traumatic brain injury, and potentially cancer metastasis.

title: Microgravity alters the expression of salivary proteins
summary: This research investigated how spaceflight and microgravity affect the submandibular salivary glands of mice. Scientists examined gland tissues from female mice on short-duration space shuttle missions (13-15 days) and male mice on a longer 30-day biosatellite mission. The study found no significant structural changes in the submandibular glands of any of the mice. However, there were notable biochemical differences based on flight duration and the sex of the animals. Female mice on shorter flights showed no significant alteration in salivary protein expression. In contrast, male mice on the 30-day flight exhibited a significant increase in the expression of specific proteins, including salivary androgen binding protein alpha (SABPα), epidermal growth factor (EGF), and nerve growth factor (NGF). These findings suggest that longer exposure to spaceflight alters secretory protein expression, and that different salivary glands respond uniquely to the space environment. The study concludes that saliva could be a valuable and easily collected biofluid for monitoring astronaut physiology and health.

title: Salivary Gland Protein Expression after Bion-M1 and Space Shuttle STS-135 Missions
summary: This research investigated the effects of spaceflight on the submandibular salivary glands of mice using tissue samples from three separate missions. The study compared glands from female mice on shorter 13-15 day space shuttle flights with male mice from a longer 30-day Bion-M1 mission. Specifically, male mice on the longer mission showed increased expression of several secretory proteins, including salivary androgen binding protein alpha (SABPα), epidermal growth factor (EGF), and nerve growth factor (NGF). In contrast, female mice on the shorter flights exhibited no significant changes in protein expression. These results indicate that spaceflight alters protein production in salivary glands, with the response being dependent on the duration of the flight and the sex of the animal. The findings also highlight that different salivary glands respond uniquely to the space environment and suggest that saliva could be a useful and non-invasive biofluid for monitoring astronaut health.

title: Response of the mouse sublingual gland to spaceflight.
summary: This research studied the sublingual salivary glands of mice flown on two space shuttle missions (STS-131 and STS-135) to understand the effects of spaceflight. The study found that while the physical structure of the gland's cells remained unchanged, the expression of specific secretory proteins was significantly altered. Interestingly, the changes in protein expression were inconsistent between the two flights; levels of key proteins like PSP and Muc19 increased in mice from the STS-131 mission but decreased in those from the STS-135 mission. Researchers suggest this difference may be related to the different ages of the mice on each flight. This response contrasts with previous findings in the parotid gland, which showed cellular damage under similar conditions. The study concludes that the biological response to spaceflight varies significantly among different glands and cell types. Ultimately, tracking these changes in salivary proteins may lead to non-invasive methods for monitoring astronaut health.

title: Effects of spaceflight on the mouse submandibular gland
summary: This research investigates how lunar gravity (1/6 g) affects the submandibular salivary glands in mice during spaceflight on the International Space Station. Using a centrifuge to simulate lunar gravity, scientists analyzed gene expression changes in the glands after the mice returned to Earth. They discovered that lunar gravity specifically increased the expression of the salivary amylase gene, Amy1, which is a known stress marker. However, genes that regulate water secretion in saliva, such as Aqp5, showed no change. The study also found an upregulation of genes essential for the cellular secretion process, including Vamp8 and small G proteins from the Rap and Rab families. These findings imply that lunar gravity enhances the cellular machinery for secreting amylase via specific signaling pathways. The research highlights Amy1 as a potential candidate for monitoring stress in salivary glands in low-gravity environments like the moon.

title: Reactivation of Latent Epstein-Barr Virus: A Comparison after Exposure to Gamma, Proton, Carbon, and Iron Radiation
summary: This research investigates how different types of radiation, similar to that experienced by astronauts, affect latent viruses. Scientists exposed a human cell line infected with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) to four radiation types: gamma rays, protons, carbon ions, and iron ions. The key finding was that all radiation types caused the dormant virus to reactivate, as measured by increased viral gene activity and higher viral loads. This reactivation occurred directly within the cells, proving it can happen without influence from the immune system. The most significant increase in viral activity was observed four days post-exposure for all radiation types. Surprisingly, gamma rays were generally more effective at inducing reactivation than the high-energy particles like protons and iron ions. This result challenges the standard concept of relative biological effectiveness (RBE) used in radiobiology for other endpoints. The study concludes that direct radiation exposure is a significant factor in the viral reactivation seen in astronauts during spaceflight.

title: The influence of spaceflight on the astronaut salivary microbiome and the search for a microbiome biomarker for viral reactivation
summary: This study is the first to investigate how spaceflight affects the astronauts' salivary microbiome and its potential link to viral reactivation. Researchers analyzed saliva from ten astronauts before, during, and after spaceflight, examining both bacterial populations and viral titers for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), HSV, and VZV. The results indicated that overall microbiome diversity and richness increased during spaceflight, but the diversity of Streptococcus, the most common oral bacteria, decreased. The abundance of certain bacterial phyla, such as Proteobacteria and Fusobacteria, increased in-flight while Actinobacteria decreased. A significant positive correlation was discovered between the richness of the microbiome and the amount of EBV detected, suggesting a link between bacterial changes and viral health. The study also identified specific bacteria that were positively or negatively correlated with EBV, suggesting they could serve as biomarkers. These findings could inform future strategies to mitigate health risks like viral reactivation during long-duration space missions.

title: The cyclic nucleotide-gated channel CNGC14 regulates root gravitropism in Arabidopsis thaliana.
summary: This research investigates how the roots of the plant Arabidopsis thaliana navigate through soil by responding to gravity. Using a new method to visualize root surface pH, the study identified distinct acidic and alkaline zones. The research challenges the idea that these pH zones are simply controlled by the activity of proton pumps (AHA H+-ATPases). Instead, the key finding is that a specific alkaline zone is actively controlled by a rapid response to the plant hormone auxin. This response pathway involves the auxin transporter AUX1, the co-receptor AFB1, and crucially, the calcium channel CNGC14. The study demonstrates that this entire auxin-CNGC14 module is essential for regulating the root surface pH. This pH regulation, in turn, is required for the root to efficiently change its growth direction in response to gravity, a process known as gravitropism.

title: Telomere length assessments of muscle stem cells in rodent and human skeletal muscle sections
summary: This research paper describes a detailed protocol for measuring telomere length in skeletal muscle stem cells (MuSCs). The method, called cryosection muscle quantitative fluorescent in situ hybridization (CRYO MuQ-FISH), allows for the analysis of these rare cells directly within their native environment in frozen tissue sections. This approach provides valuable insights into cellular dysfunction and aging in diseased conditions like Duchenne muscular dystrophy. A key advantage of this protocol is its ability to perform measurements at the single-cell level, overcoming the limitations of methods that require cell isolation or provide only population averages. The technique is ideal for use with archival tissue samples from both rodent and human sources. Furthermore, the protocol utilizes a free, semi-automated software called Telometer for robust data collection and analysis. The described methodology offers outputs for both total and mean telomere intensity per nucleus. This provides researchers with a powerful tool to study the role of telomeres in muscle biology and disease.

title: Persistent NF-Œ∫B activation in muscle stem cells induces proliferation-independent telomere shortening
summary: This research investigates why muscle stem cells (MuSCs) become less effective at repairing damage in chronic muscle disorders like Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). The study reveals that persistent activation of a signaling pathway, NF-κB, is a primary cause of this dysfunction. Researchers found that prolonged NF-κB signaling in MuSCs leads to the premature shortening of telomeres, the protective caps on chromosomes. Crucially, this telomere shortening occurs through a mechanism that is independent of cell replication, which is the more common cause of such attrition. The paper identifies that NF-κB activation downregulates a key protein, Ku80, which is essential for telomere protection and DNA repair. This loss of Ku80 results in increased DNA damage at the telomeres, leading to the exhaustion of the muscle stem cell pool and impaired muscle regeneration. These findings, consistent in both mouse models and human DMD patients, link chronic inflammation directly to stem cell failure and the progression of muscular dystrophy.

title: Piezo1 regulates the regenerative capacity of skeletal muscles via orchestration of stem cell morphological states.
summary: This research explores how the physical shape of muscle stem cells (MuSCs) influences their role in tissue regeneration. The study reveals that quiescent MuSCs are morphologically diverse, exhibiting varying numbers of cellular protrusions, and can be classified into three functional states: responsive, intermediate, and sensory. Following an injury, these cells dynamically change shape, shifting towards the 'responsive' state, which has fewer protrusions and is primed to act first. The mechanosensing protein Piezo1 is identified as the key regulator controlling this transition between states. Pharmacological activation of Piezo1 is sufficient to prime MuSCs into a more responsive form. Conversely, deleting Piezo1 impairs this transition, a condition that mirrors the phenotype observed in dystrophic muscles. The findings also show that reactivating Piezo1 in dystrophic muscle models can correct these morphological defects and enhance regenerative capacity, highlighting Piezo1 as a potential therapeutic target.

title: Impacts of radiation exposure, hindlimb unloading, and recovery on murine skeletal muscle cell telomere length.
summary: This research explores how spaceflight conditions affect skeletal muscle using a ground-based mouse model that simulates microgravity and radiation exposure. The study combines hindlimb unloading (HLS) to mimic weightlessness and ionizing radiation (IR) to replicate cosmic rays. The key finding is that the combination of HLS and IR causes telomeres to lengthen specifically in muscle stem cells and myofiber nuclei. This telomere elongation was not observed in nearby endothelial cells, indicating a response specific to myogenic cell types. Unlike astronauts' blood cells, where telomeres shorten upon returning to Earth, the telomeres in the mouse muscle cells remained elongated even after a two-week recovery period. The researchers found that this lengthening was not due to the enzyme telomerase. Instead, the results suggest an alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) pathway may be responsible. These findings reveal a unique cellular mechanism in muscle acclimatization to spaceflight-like conditions, which is crucial for understanding astronaut health.

title: Ethylene-induced flavonol accumulation in guard cells suppresses reactive oxygen species and modulates stomatal aperture
summary: This research investigates how plants regulate the aperture of their stomata, the microscopic pores on leaves responsible for gas exchange and water transpiration. The study focuses on the guard cells of the plant Arabidopsis thaliana, which control stomatal opening and closing. Researchers found that antioxidant compounds called flavonols specifically accumulate within these guard cells. These flavonols act to suppress reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are key signaling molecules that promote stomatal closure in response to the hormone abscisic acid (ABA). By reducing ROS levels, flavonols effectively slow down the rate of ABA-induced stomatal closure. The study also reveals that the plant hormone ethylene positively regulates this process by increasing the synthesis of flavonols in the guard cells. Therefore, higher ethylene levels lead to more flavonols, lower ROS, and a more modulated stomatal response. This mechanism provides plants with a way to fine-tune their response to environmental stress by controlling water loss.

title: Transcriptional and Hormonal Regulation of Gravitropism of Woody Stems in Populus.
summary: This research investigates the molecular and hormonal mechanisms behind how Populus (poplar) trees reorient their woody stems against gravity, a process known as gravitropism. The study identifies that gravity is perceived in specialized cells through the settling of starch-filled amyloplasts, which triggers the relocalization of the PIN3 auxin transporter protein. This process leads to the asymmetrical formation of a specialized tissue called tension wood on the upper side of the stem, which generates a contractile force to pull the stem upward. A key finding is the central role of the ARBORKNOX2 (ARK2) transcription factor; increasing its expression enhances the bending response and accelerates the maturation of tension wood fibers, while decreasing it has the opposite effect. The plant hormone gibberellic acid (GA) was also found to stimulate the rate of tension wood formation and enhance the stem's response to auxin. The paper proposes a model where PIN3 directs auxin transport toward the wood-forming cambium on the upper side of the stem to trigger tension wood formation. Finally, computational analysis of genome-wide data helped model the transcriptional networks governing these developmental processes.
