title: Spaceflight-induced vertebral bone loss in ovariectomized rats is associated with increased bone marrow adiposity and no change in bone formation
summary: This study investigated the effects of a 14-day spaceflight on the lumbar vertebrae of ovariectomized rats, a model for post-menopausal bone changes. The key finding was that rats flown in space experienced a 32% loss in cancellous bone mass compared to ground controls. This bone loss was associated with a dramatic 306% increase in bone marrow adipose tissue (fat), resulting from both a higher number and larger size of fat cells. Analysis showed that bone resorption (the breakdown of bone tissue by osteoclasts) was significantly elevated in the flight group. However, the rate of new bone formation and the activity of bone-building cells (osteoblasts) were not altered by spaceflight. These results indicate that spaceflight-induced bone loss in this model is driven by increased bone resorption without a compensatory increase in bone formation. This imbalance, or 'defective coupling,' suggests that under the conditions of spaceflight and hormonal deficiency, mesenchymal stem cells may be diverted to create fat cells instead of new bone-forming cells.

title: Role of oestrogen receptor signaling in skeletal response to leptin in female ob/ob mice.
summary: This research investigates why leptin-deficient mice, known as ob/ob mice, exhibit a contradictory bone growth pattern, with shorter femurs (appendicular bones) but longer spines (axial bones) compared to normal mice. The study explored the role of estrogen receptor (ER) signaling in this phenomenon. Researchers confirmed this contrasting growth pattern and found corresponding differences in growth-related proteins within the femoral and spinal growth plates. A key finding was that the expression of estrogen receptor alpha (ERα) was significantly lower in the femur but higher in the spine of ob/ob mice, and its expression level was positively correlated with bone length. However, when the researchers attempted to manipulate this system using ER antagonists, the drugs had no effect on bone growth in the leptin-deficient mice, whereas they worked as expected in normal mice. This suggests that while region-specific ERα expression is associated with the contrasting bone growth, leptin deficiency blunts or overrides the normal regulatory effects of estrogen signaling. The precise mechanism of interaction between leptin and estrogen receptors in bone growth remains to be explored.

title: Effects of hypothalamic leptin gene therapy on osteopetrosis in leptin-deficient mice.
summary: This research investigates a mild form of the bone disease osteopetrosis in leptin-deficient (ob/ob) mice, which is characterized by the impaired replacement of cartilage with bone during growth. The study aimed to determine if this condition resolves on its own with age and if it can be reversed by restoring leptin. By analyzing the femurs of mice at different ages, the researchers concluded that the condition is not entirely self-limiting, as abnormal cartilage persisted into skeletal maturity in the leptin-deficient mice. To test for reversibility, the team used hypothalamic gene therapy to restore leptin signaling in the mice. This treatment successfully reversed the osteopetrosis, leading to a significant reduction of cartilage in the femur. The removal of cartilage was associated with an increase in overall bone turnover, involving both bone-resorbing osteoclasts and bone-forming osteoblasts. These findings demonstrate that leptin is crucial for normal skeletal maturation and that the osteopetrotic condition in these mice can be reversed by restoring central leptin signaling.

title: Leptin stimulates bone formation in ob/ob mice at doses having minimal impact on energy metabolism.
summary: This research investigates how the hormone leptin affects bone formation and energy metabolism at different concentrations. The study used leptin-deficient (ob/ob) mice, which were continuously infused with varying doses of leptin for 12 days. Researchers found that bone formation processes were stimulated at very low leptin doses, specifically at infusion rates of 7–17 ng/h. In contrast, significantly higher doses of 40–80 ng/h were required to impact centrally-mediated functions like appetite and energy metabolism. Gene expression analysis confirmed that low-dose leptin activated bone-related signaling pathways in the tibia with minimal effect on the hypothalamus. These findings suggest that leptin acts directly on the skeleton, a process described as a peripheral action. The blood-brain barrier (BBB) limits leptin's entry into the central nervous system, creating a mechanism where bone growth can be promoted at lower hormone levels. This ensures that the bone-building actions of leptin are not suppressed by its appetite-reducing effects, which require higher concentrations to act on the brain.

title: Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue Deficiency Increases Disuse-Induced Bone Loss in Male Mice
summary: This research investigated the role of bone marrow adipose tissue (MAT) in bone loss resulting from mechanical disuse, a condition analogous to what astronauts experience in microgravity. Scientists hypothesized that an absence of MAT would be protective against bone loss, as both fat and bone cells derive from the same precursor. Using a mouse model genetically deficient in MAT, they simulated the effects of spaceflight via a two-week hindlimb unloading experiment. Contrary to their hypothesis, the study found that MAT-deficient mice experienced significantly greater cancellous bone loss compared to normal mice. These mice exhibited elevated rates of both bone formation and resorption, indicating a high-turnover state where bone breakdown outpaced formation. Further analysis revealed that the molecular pathways for bone loss were different in the MAT-deficient mice. The study's key finding is that MAT deficiency does not prevent disuse-induced bone loss and, in fact, appears to exacerbate it. These results challenge the assumption that MAT is detrimental and suggest it may play a complex, perhaps even protective, role in bone health during mechanical unloading.

title: Metabolic Coupling Between Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue and Hematopoiesis
summary: This research investigates the role of the mannose receptor C-type 1 (Mrc1) in the development of obesity and associated inflammation. Using a mouse model, scientists fed mice lacking the Mrc1 gene (Mrc1−/−) and normal mice a high-fat diet for 20 weeks. The study found that Mrc1 deficiency protected the mice from many negative effects of the diet. These mice gained less weight, had better glucose and insulin responses, and showed reduced fat accumulation in the liver. These protective effects were linked to changes in the bone marrow, where the production of inflammatory myeloid cells was reduced, and the number of adipocytes increased. Consequently, Mrc1-deficient mice had fewer pro-inflammatory immune cells circulating in their blood and infiltrating metabolic tissues like fat and the liver. The findings suggest that Mrc1 is a key player in the immunometabolic response to diet-induced obesity by regulating bone marrow function and systemic inflammation.

title: Maintenance of near normal bone mass and architecture in lethally irradiated female mice following adoptive transfer with as few as 750 purified hematopoietic stem cells.
summary: This research investigates a method to restore bone marrow in mice after lethal total-body irradiation (TBI) while avoiding significant bone damage. High-dose radiation typically causes irreversible bone loss (osteopenia), which complicates the interpretation of research results. The study aimed to determine if transplanting a very small number of purified hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) could effectively restore the blood-forming system without harming the skeleton. Researchers lethally irradiated mice and then engrafted them with as few as 750 purified HSCs. The results showed that this technique successfully reconstituted the hematopoietic system with donor-derived cells. Crucially, this method resulted in minimal collateral damage to the bone, maintaining near-normal bone mass and architecture two months after the procedure. These findings provide strong evidence for efficient engraftment with purified HSCs after TBI. The approach serves as a valuable new tool for investigating how hematopoietic cells regulate bone metabolism without the confounding factor of radiation-induced bone loss.

title: Effect of leptin deficiency on the skeletal response to hindlimb unloading in adult male mice.
summary: This research investigates if the hormone leptin is required for bone loss caused by skeletal unloading, a process that simulates microgravity conditions. The study compared normal (wild type) mice with genetically leptin-deficient (ob/ob) mice using a technique called hindlimb unloading (HU). Researchers hypothesized that the absence of leptin would reduce the amount of bone lost during unloading. However, the results demonstrated that both groups of mice experienced significant bone loss in their femurs and vertebrae. This loss was associated with an increase in osteoclasts, the cells responsible for bone resorption. The amount of bone density and volume lost was virtually identical between the normal and leptin-deficient mice. The study's key finding is that leptin is not essential for bone loss induced by unweighting. This suggests that other biological pathways are responsible for skeletal degradation in microgravity environments.

title: Thermoneutral housing attenuates premature cancellous bone loss in male C57BL/6J mice
summary: This research investigates the impact of housing temperature on premature bone loss in male C57BL/6J mice, a common model for studying age-related skeletal decline in humans. The study tested whether housing mice at a warmer, thermoneutral temperature (32°C) could prevent the cancellous bone loss typically observed at standard laboratory room temperatures (22°C). Results showed that mice housed at the standard, cooler temperature experienced significant reductions in cancellous bone volume in their femur and vertebrae. Conversely, this premature bone loss was completely abolished in mice housed at the thermoneutral temperature. The protective effect of the warmer environment was attributed to increased rates of bone formation and decreased rates of bone resorption. While thermoneutral housing led to higher abdominal fat and serum leptin, it did not alter bone marrow adiposity. The study concludes that the magnitude of temperature-induced bone loss is similar in both male and female mice. These findings highlight housing temperature as a critical experimental variable that significantly influences bone metabolism in mouse models.

title: Effects of Spaceflight on Cancellous and Cortical Bone in Proximal Femur in Growing Rats
summary: This research investigates the effects of microgravity on the bone structure of growing rats by analyzing archived femur bones from three separate Space Shuttle missions. The missions varied in duration from 4 to 14 days and involved different strains, ages, and sexes of rats. Using micro-computed tomography, scientists examined changes in the porous inner (cancellous) bone and the dense outer (cortical) bone of the proximal femur. The consistent key finding was that spaceflight caused a significant reduction in cancellous bone volume, a condition known as osteopenia. This effect was observed in both male and ovariectomized female rats, with the latter group showing net bone loss compared to pre-flight levels. Conversely, the thickness of the outer cortical bone remained unchanged across all experiments. The study concludes that even short-duration spaceflight leads to site-specific bone loss in the clinically relevant femoral head, underscoring the negative impact of microgravity on skeletal health.

title: Evidence for increased thermogenesis in female C57BL/6J mice housed aboard the international space station
summary: This research investigated how spaceflight affects heat production, or thermogenesis, in female mice housed on the International Space Station for 37 days. Researchers hypothesized that the microgravity environment would limit the mice's ability to use behaviors like huddling to stay warm, forcing them to rely more on internal metabolic heat generation. To test this, scientists analyzed gene expression in the animals' brown adipose tissue (BAT), which specializes in heat production, and white adipose tissue (WAT). The study found a significant increase in the expression of genes associated with non-shivering thermogenesis in the BAT of flight mice, most notably a 1.5-fold increase in the Ucp-1 gene. Concurrently, the WAT of flight mice showed gene expression changes indicating increased glucose uptake, metabolism, and a 'browning' process, where fat-storing tissue develops heat-producing capabilities. The study concludes that mice in space experience elevated adaptive thermogenesis compared to ground-based controls. This finding is significant as increased thermogenesis could be a confounding factor in space research, potentially exaggerating other physiological responses like bone loss or altering the body's response to radiation.

title: Leptin and environmental temperature as determinants of bone marrow adiposity in female mice
summary: This research investigates how environmental temperature and the hormone leptin regulate bone marrow adipose tissue (BMAT) in female mice. Researchers observed that mice housed at a warmer, thermoneutral temperature (32°C) develop more BMAT than mice at standard room temperature (22°C). To understand leptin's role, one experiment supplemented mice at 32°C with leptin, which resulted in decreased BMAT and increased bone formation. This effect was shown to be independent of food intake. A second experiment used leptin-deficient mice and confirmed that the BMAT increase from warmer housing occurs even without leptin. However, providing a low dose of leptin to these deficient mice counteracted the temperature-induced BMAT accumulation. The study's key finding is that increased housing temperature and increased leptin have independent but opposing effects on BMAT. While warmer temperatures promote the accumulation of fat in bone marrow, leptin acts as a negative regulator to reduce it.

title: Small changes in thermoregulation influence cancellous bone turnover balance in distal femur metaphysis in growing female mice
summary: This research investigates how minor variations in housing conditions affect bone health in growing female mice. The study is based on the premise that standard laboratory housing temperatures (~22°C) are below the mice's thermoneutral zone, inducing cold stress that can lead to bone loss and potentially skew experimental results. Researchers compared mice housed individually at 22°C with those housed at a slightly warmer 26°C and others group-housed at 22°C. The key finding was that mice housed alone at 22°C experienced a dramatic decrease in cancellous bone volume in their distal femur. This premature bone loss was significantly lessened, though not entirely prevented, in mice housed at 26°C or in groups at 22°C. These alternative housing conditions help mice better maintain body temperature, reducing the physiological cost of thermogenesis. The study concludes that even modest differences in housing temperature or social grouping can substantially influence skeletal outcomes, highlighting the importance of carefully controlling environmental variables in preclinical bone research.

title: Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue Is Not Required for Reconstitution of the Immune System Following Irradiation in Male Mice
summary: This study investigates if Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue (BMAT) is essential for the immune system and skeleton to recover following severe injury. Both groups were exposed to lethal radiation and then received a transplant of healthy hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) to rebuild their immune systems. The key finding was that both the BMAT-deficient and normal mice demonstrated excellent and comparable immune reconstitution, successfully regenerating their B and T cell populations. These results suggest that BMAT does not function as a critical energy source for bone marrow recovery after such an event and that skeletal abnormalities in BMAT-deficient mice are likely due to underlying defects in genetic signaling rather than the absence of fat tissue.

title: Simulated Microgravity Promotes Horizontal Gene Transfer of Antimicrobial Resistance Genes between Bacterial Genera in the Absence of Antibiotic Selective Pressure
summary: This study investigates if simulated microgravity (SMG) enhances the transfer of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes between different bacterial species. Researchers are concerned this process, known as horizontal gene transfer (HGT), could pose a health risk to astronauts on long missions. The experiment involved co-culturing a donor bacterium, Acinetobacter pittii, carrying resistance genes with a recipient bacterium, Staphylococcus aureus, under both SMG and normal 1G gravity. This was done without antibiotic pressure to see if transfer would occur naturally. The key finding was that HGT was significantly increased under SMG conditions. As a result, the S. aureus strains acquired the genes and became newly resistant to the antibiotic oxacillin. This novel research demonstrates for the first time that the space environment may promote the spread of AMR, a significant consideration for astronaut health during future space exploration.

title: Understanding the Complexities and Changes of the Astronaut Microbiome for Successful Long-Duration Space Missions
summary: This research paper reviews the critical impact of long-duration space missions on the human microbiome, the complex community of microbes essential for regulating host health. The unique stressors of spaceflight, such as microgravity, radiation, and confinement, are known to cause significant physiological changes in astronauts. Many of these alterations occur at the microbiome level, which can subsequently affect immunity, bone health, cognitive function, and overall metabolism. The paper highlights that understanding these microbial shifts is vital for assessing health risks and developing effective countermeasures for future missions. Studies, including the NASA Twins Study, show that while spaceflight induces distinct changes in microbiome composition, some of these effects can revert to baseline after returning to Earth. The research emphasizes the interconnected relationship between the space environment, the astronaut's body, and their microbiome. Ultimately, the findings underscore the necessity of incorporating microbiome data into mission planning to ensure the success and safety of human exploration beyond low Earth orbit.

title: Toward sustainable space exploration: a roadmap for harnessing the power of microorganisms.
summary: This research paper outlines a roadmap for using microbial biotechnologies to achieve sustainable, long-duration human space exploration, reducing dependency on Earth's resources. The authors propose that microorganisms are uniquely suited for in situ resource utilization (ISRU) and creating closed-loop systems for life support. Key applications highlighted include purifying air in habitats, processing human waste into valuable resources, and supporting food production. The paper also explores using microbes for biomining essential elements from regolith, manufacturing pharmaceuticals and construction materials, and recycling synthetic waste like plastics and electronics. Furthermore, it discusses the potential of microorganisms for energy collection and storage. The development of these technologies is presented as crucial for enabling missions beyond low-Earth orbit. The authors also emphasize that these space-focused innovations will have direct applications for tackling environmental and sustainability challenges on Earth.

title: Roll maneuvers are essential for active reorientation of Caenorhabditis elegans in 3D media
summary: This research investigates the three-dimensional locomotion of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, a key model organism in biology. While previous studies have largely focused on its 2D movement, this paper identifies a unique 3D behavior essential for navigating its environment called a "roll maneuver." This maneuver involves a torsional, or twisting, motion of the worm's body, which rotates the plane of its wave-like undulations. By combining these rolls with standard planar turns, C. elegans can reorient itself in any direction, allowing for the complete exploration of 3D media like soil or water. The study reveals that these roll maneuvers are significantly faster when the nematode is swimming compared to when it is burrowing. This increased speed is not due to a change in the worm's physical motion but is attributed to a "hydrodynamic enhancement mechanism," where viscous fluid forces surprisingly aid the rotation. This finding is notable because hydrodynamics typically hinder other movements like forward swimming and 2D turns. The researchers successfully developed a mathematical model to describe this unique behavioral state, providing key insights into 3D neuromuscular control.

title: Microfluidic Device for Studying Nematodes
summary: This research paper presents an improved method for synchronizing Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans) nematodes for high-throughput experiments. The standard technique, bleach synchronization, can be harmful to the embryos and yield inconsistent results. As an alternative, the researchers developed a protocol using commercially available mesh filters to physically separate embryos from adult and larval nematodes based on size. This new filtration method was found to yield significantly more embryos per plate compared to the traditional bleach protocol. The study also demonstrated that embryos collected via filtration develop into healthier and longer larvae. Furthermore, the gentle nature of the filtration technique did not negatively affect the nematodes' response in subsequent drug sensitivity assays. In conclusion, the paper establishes mesh filtration as a scalable, efficient, and less damaging alternative for preparing large, synchronized populations of C. elegans embryos for research.

title: NemaFlex: A microfluidics-based technology for standardized measurement of muscular strength of C. elegans.
summary: This research introduces a novel microfluidics-based technology called 'NemaFlex' for the standardized measurement of muscular strength in the nematode C. elegans. The study addresses the challenge that previous force measurements in C. elegans were inconsistent, as they were influenced by the animal's behavior and locomotion. NemaFlex works by having the worm crawl through an array of flexible micropillars and quantifying its strength based on the degree to which it deflects these pillars. The researchers optimized the pillar design to create a highly resistive environment, yielding a reliable metric called Maximum Exertable Force (MEF) that is independent of the worm's gait. The system's accuracy was validated using genetic mutants and a muscle-contracting agent. Additionally, a scaling factor was developed to account for variations in animal size, enabling accurate comparative studies. The paper establishes NemaFlex as a powerful tool for investigating the molecular mechanisms of muscle decline, particularly those related to aging, disease, and space travel, and for screening potential therapeutic interventions.

title: Swim exercise in Caenorhabditis elegans extends neuromuscular and gut healthspan, enhances learning ability, and protects against neurodegeneration
summary: This research establishes a swim exercise protocol for the nematode C. elegans to investigate the system-wide health benefits of physical activity. Scientists discovered that multiple daily swim sessions during the worm's early adulthood led to significant improvements across multiple biological systems. The exercise regimen enhanced neuromuscular function, intestinal health, and cognitive abilities. Notably, the training provided protection against neurodegeneration in worm models of human conditions like Alzheimer's and Huntington's disease. A crucial finding was that the positive effects of this early-life exercise were long-lasting, persisting well into the organism's midlife. These systemic benefits were linked to improved muscle gene expression, healthier mitochondrial networks, and enhanced whole-animal mitochondrial respiration. This study validates C. elegans as a powerful genetic model for dissecting the molecular mechanisms through which exercise promotes healthy aging across the entire body.

title: Molecular muscle experiment: Hardware and operational lessons for future astrobiology space experiments
summary: This research outlines the extensive preparation for the Molecular Muscle Experiment (MME), designed to study spaceflight-induced muscle decline on the International Space Station (ISS) using the model organism C. elegans. As previously used hardware was unavailable, the team had to design, develop, and validate new culture bags and experimental containers. A key challenge was ensuring adequate oxygen for the worms, leading to the discovery that the worms' diet significantly impacts their oxygen consumption rate. The researchers found that worms on a bacterial diet (OP50) required more oxygen than those on a chemically defined medium, which explained why certain bag materials failed during testing. Through rigorous ground-based experiments, the team optimized culture volume, internal hardware design, and experimental timelines to support worm growth. They also simulated various launch and transport scenarios, including delays and passive temperature control, to ensure the experiment's viability. The paper presents these hardware solutions and operational lessons to aid future space biology research.

title: Tart Cherry Increases Lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans by Altering Metabolic Signaling Pathways
summary: This research investigates the effects of tart cherry extract (TCE) on the lifespan of the nematode *Caenorhabditis elegans*. The study found that supplementing the worms' diet with specific concentrations of TCE (6 and 12 μg/mL) significantly increased their mean lifespan by over 25%. Researchers identified that TCE's benefits are linked to its influence on key metabolic signaling pathways. The extract upregulates the expression of longevity-related genes, such as *daf-16* and *aak-2*, which are crucial for metabolism and stress resistance. Furthermore, TCE improved mitochondrial function by increasing spare respiration capacity and enhanced the expression of genes that combat oxidative stress. The study confirmed the central role of these pathways, as the lifespan-extending effects of TCE were not observed in mutant worms lacking the *daf-16* or *aak-2* genes. In conclusion, the findings indicate that tart cherry extract promotes longevity in *C. elegans* by reducing oxidative stress and improving mitochondrial health, primarily through the DAF-16/FOXO signaling pathway.

title: A region of UNC-89 (obscurin) lying between two protein kinase domains is a highly elastic spring required for proper sarcomere organization
summary: This research investigates a specific, non-domain region within the giant muscle protein UNC-89 in the nematode C. elegans. This "interkinase region" is situated between two protein kinase domains and is conserved in mammalian homologs like obscurin. Using single-molecule force spectroscopy, the study demonstrates that this region is highly elastic and functions as an entropic spring. To determine its in vivo role, researchers used CRISPR/Cas9 to create nematodes with this specific region deleted. These engineered animals displayed severe disorganization of their muscle sarcomeres, the fundamental contractile units of muscle. Consequently, the nematodes with the deletion exhibited defective locomotion and reduced muscle force generation. Super-resolution microscopy revealed that the muscle cells contained extra, improperly formed A-bands. These findings establish that the elastic, spring-like interkinase region of UNC-89 is essential for maintaining proper sarcomere structure and overall muscle function.

title: NemaLife chip: a micropillar-based microfluidic culture device optimized for aging studies in crawling C. elegans
summary: This research introduces the "NemaLife chip," a novel microfluidic device designed for whole-life aging studies of the nematode C. elegans. The chip features a unique micropillar arena that allows the worms to crawl naturally, mimicking their typical behavior on an agar plate. This design avoids the physiological stress associated with swimming in other microfluidic systems. Integrated sieve channels automatically separate adult worms from their progeny, eliminating the need for labor-intensive manual transfers or reproduction-blocking chemicals that can skew results. Researchers optimized the device's geometry and feeding protocols to ensure lifespan outcomes were comparable to standard culture methods. A key finding is that worms cultured in similar devices without micropillars exhibited reduced lifespans and increased stress. The device's reliability was validated using well-established aging mutants and RNAi knockdown experiments. The NemaLife chip represents a significant advance, enabling more efficient and accurate research into lifespan and healthspan.

title: Spaceflight affects neuronal morphology and alters transcellular degradation of neuronal debris in adult Caenorhabditis elegans
summary: This study investigates the effects of spaceflight on the nervous system using the nematode C. elegans as a model organism. Researchers sent adult worms to the International Space Station for five days and compared their neurons to ground-based controls. A key finding was that spaceflight induced hyperbranching, an excessive growth of new branches, in adult sensory neurons, indicating that the space environment can alter the physical structure of mature neurons. Additionally, the study examined neurons under proteotoxic stress. In these stressed animals, spaceflight led to a significant accumulation of neuronal waste products in the surrounding tissues. This suggests that spaceflight impairs the crucial transcellular process responsible for clearing debris released from neurons. Overall, the research reveals that the space environment can significantly impact adult neuronal morphology and cellular waste clearance. These findings highlight potential neurological risks for long-duration space missions and emphasize the need for further study and the development of effective countermeasures.

title: Microfluidics-integrated spaceflight hardware for measuring muscle strength of Caenorhabditis elegans on the International Space Station.
summary: This research focuses on the development of specialized hardware to measure the muscle strength of the nematode C. elegans aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Previous studies showed that microgravity alters the expression of genes related to muscle maintenance in these worms, but it was unknown if this directly translated to a loss of physical strength. To investigate this, the researchers redesigned a microfluidic device called NemaFlex, creating a spaceflight-ready version named NemaFlex-S. This new system is designed to overcome the challenges of on-orbit experiments, such as limited astronaut time, safety protocols, and the need to handle mixed-age worm cultures. Key innovations include a chip that sorts worms by size into individual chambers, a custom worm-loading apparatus (WLA) to prevent leaks and contamination, and optimized fluid-handling protocols. The paper details the successful Earth-based validation of this integrated hardware. These validation studies confirmed the system's readiness and led to its deployment on the ISS to conduct multi-generational studies on muscle adaptation in space.

title: A Compact Imaging Platform for Conducting C. elegans Phenotypic Assays on Earth and in Spaceflight.
summary: This research paper introduces a 3D-printed Compact Imaging Platform (CIP) designed for studying the model organism Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans). The device integrates with a smart-device camera, requires no external optics or mechanical focusing, and is powered by a standard USB connection. Its small, lightweight, and portable design makes it ideal for use in various settings, including inside temperature-controlled incubators. The researchers validated the platform on Earth by demonstrating its compatibility with different C. elegans substrates like agar plates, liquid droplets, and microfluidic chips. Key findings show that the behavioral and locomotory data collected using the CIP for wild-type and mutant worms are in good agreement with established literature. The platform successfully distinguished phenotypic differences between mutant strains. The paper concludes that the CIP's simplicity, low power consumption, and small footprint address major constraints of spaceflight research. This makes it a highly promising tool for future whole-organism phenotypic studies aboard the International Space Station (ISS), where payload size, weight, and crew time are limited.

title: Mitochondrial sulfide promotes life span and health span through distinct mechanisms in developing versus adult treated Caenorhabditis elegans.
summary: This research investigates the effects of a mitochondrion-targeting hydrogen sulfide donor, AP39, on aging in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. The study found that administering small doses of AP39 from birth extended both the lifespan and healthspan of the worms by preserving mitochondrial integrity. This effect was dependent on H2S metabolism enzymes and the FoxO/daf-16 signaling pathway. In contrast, when the treatment was started in adult worms that already showed signs of aging, it improved their healthspan but did not extend their overall lifespan. This adult-onset health improvement was governed by a distinct mechanism involving the elt-6/elt-3 transcription factor circuit, which rejuvenated the expression of genes related to mitochondria, the cytoskeleton, and peroxisomes. The findings also reveal that while the Nrf2 oxidative stress pathway is required for lifespan extension, it is not necessary for the observed healthspan benefits. This research suggests that targeting mitochondrial sulfide is a promising therapeutic strategy for promoting healthy aging, even when started later in life.

title: Bisphosphonates attenuate age-related muscle decline in Caenorhabditis elegans.
summary: This research explores the potential of the bisphosphonate drug, zoledronic acid (ZA), to combat age-related muscle decline (sarcopenia). Using the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans as a model, scientists found that low doses of ZA extended both the lifespan and healthspan of the worms, as measured by their movement. Higher doses, however, proved to be either detrimental or lethal. The study revealed that the beneficial effects of ZA are linked to improved muscle health at a cellular level. Specifically, ZA treatment delayed the age-related breakdown of myofibrillar structures and mitochondrial networks within muscle cells. The researchers also identified several key genetic pathways, including the daf-16/FOXO stress response pathway, that are necessary for ZA to produce these positive effects. The findings suggest that bisphosphonates can directly protect against muscle aging, independent of their usual function in bone. This makes them a promising candidate for an immediately applicable anti-sarcopenia therapy in humans.

title: Spaceflight Induces Strength Decline in Caenorhabditis elegans
summary: This research investigates the effects of spaceflight on muscle strength using the nematode worm, Caenorhabditis elegans, as a model organism on the International Space Station. The study compared wild-type worms with a mutant strain modeling Duchenne muscular dystrophy (dys-1) to assess how a predisposition to muscle weakness affects the response to space. Key findings show that spaceflight induced a significant decline in neuromuscular strength in both worm strains. Notably, the dys-1 mutant worms experienced a more pronounced strength reduction compared to their wild-type counterparts. Transcriptomic analysis of the space-flown worms revealed gene expression changes consistent with previous cross-species studies, including upregulated stress response pathways and downregulated mitochondrial and cytoskeletal functions. The study further identified decreased neuronal function, particularly abnormal calcium handling and acetylcholine signaling, as a likely contributor to this strength loss. title: Metabolic model predictions enable targeted microbiome manipulation through precision prebiotics.
summary: This research addresses the challenge of selectively manipulating beneficial bacteria within a microbiome. The authors introduce the concept of 'precision prebiotics,' which are specific nutritional supplements designed to boost the population of a single target microbial species. Using computational metabolic modeling, they aimed to identify such prebiotics for a simple two-species microbiome in the worm Caenorhabditis elegans. The goal was to increase the abundance of the protective species Pseudomonas lurida MYb11 without affecting its competitor, Ochrobactrum vermis MYb71. The model predicted several compounds, four of which—L-serine, L-threonine, D-mannitol, and γ-aminobutyric acid—were experimentally validated. These compounds successfully and specifically increased the MYb11 population in laboratory cultures. Furthermore, L-serine was also shown to be effective inside the host organism, increasing MYb11 abundance in the worm's gut. The study concludes that metabolic modeling is a powerful and effective strategy for designing targeted microbiome interventions.

title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations underpinning spaceflight dermatology.
summary: This research investigates the underlying biological reasons for the common dermatological issues experienced by astronauts during spaceflight. Using a systems biology approach, the study analyzed gene expression data from the skin of space-flown mice and from various samples from astronauts, including those from the NASA Twins Study and the Inspiration4 mission. The key findings point to several molecular drivers for skin health risks in space. These include significant changes related to DNA damage and repair, mitochondrial dysregulation, and alterations in genes associated with skin barrier function and collagen formation. A machine learning model was also used to identify specific gene pairings involved in the skin's response to the space environment. Notably, the research also highlights the body's remarkable ability to re-adapt post-flight, as evidenced by the re-tuning of gene expression upon returning to Earth. These findings provide a molecular framework for understanding spaceflight-induced skin problems and will guide the development of future countermeasures to protect astronaut health.

title: Identification and characterization of a skin microbiome on Caenorhabditis elegans suggests environmental microbes confer cuticle protection
summary: This research identifies and characterizes a 'skin microbiome' on the cuticle of the nematode C. elegans. Using a novel micro-swabbing tool and 16S rRNA gene sequencing, the study reveals that the community of bacteria on the nematode's surface is distinct from the microbes within its gut. The researchers found that certain bacteria, like Enterobacter sp. JUb101, preferentially reside on the cuticle, whereas others, such as Stenotrophomonas indicatrix JUb19, are primarily found in the gut. A key finding is that this skin microbiome provides a functional benefit to the host. Nematodes colonized by this microbial community showed enhanced cuticle integrity and were more resistant to harsh chemical environments. This protective effect was particularly evident in mutant worms with pre-existing cuticle defects. The study concludes that this external microbiome confers a fitness advantage and establishes C. elegans as a valuable model for studying skin-microbe interactions.

title: Protein kinase 2 of the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89 regulates mitochondrial morphology and function
summary: This research investigates the function of the protein kinase 2 (PK2) domain within UNC-89, a giant protein crucial for muscle structure in the nematode C. elegans. Scientists used CRISPR to create a mutation that specifically inactivates the PK2 domain, expecting to find defects in muscle organization or function. Surprisingly, these mutant worms displayed normal muscle structure and even moved faster than wild-type worms. The primary finding was an unexpected change in the muscle cells' mitochondria, which became highly fragmented. This fragmentation was linked to an increased association of the mitochondrial fission protein, DRP-1. The study also revealed that the mutant worms had altered energy metabolism, including higher ATP levels and changes in mitochondrial respiration, suggesting a state of uncoupling. These results point to a novel signaling pathway from the muscle sarcomere to the mitochondria, mediated by UNC-89 PK2, which helps regulate mitochondrial shape and match energy production to the cell's needs.

title: New perspectives on viable microbial communities in low-biomass cleanroom environments
summary: This study introduces a method to differentiate between live and dead bacteria in low-biomass environments like spacecraft assembly cleanrooms. Researchers combined propidium monoazide (PMA) treatment, which blocks DNA from dead cells, with advanced pyrosequencing and DNA microarray analysis. The key finding was that only 1% to 10% of the total bacterial DNA detected originated from viable, or living, cells. This suggests that conventional DNA analysis significantly overestimates the live microbial population. The study also revealed that the diversity of viable bacteria varied with the cleanroom's use. Cleanrooms housing mission-critical spacecraft hardware contained a less diverse community dominated by a few hardy organisms. In contrast, an inactive cleanroom without hardware harbored a much more diverse viable bacterial population. This research provides a pioneering approach to accurately assess the viable microbial communities in controlled environments crucial for planetary protection.

title: Microbial existence in controlled habitats and their resistance to space conditions
summary: This research investigates the impact of gut microbiota on the progression of tuberculosis (TB) in BALB/c mice. The study compared conventional laboratory mice with mice that were given a gut microbiome from wild mice (WildR). The key finding was that WildR mice demonstrated better control of the initial bacterial load in their lungs during the acute phase of the infection. However, this early advantage diminished as the disease progressed into the chronic stage. TB infection was found to cause gut dysbiosis, significantly altering the microbial community composition in both groups of mice. Despite the differences in their gut microbiomes and early pathogen control, the overall lung pathology, including the formation and structure of immune lesions, was similar between the two groups. T cell responses in the lungs were less pronounced in WildR mice during the acute phase, which corresponded to their lower bacterial numbers at that time. Ultimately, the study concludes that while the wild mouse microbiota provides a modest, temporary benefit, it does not fundamentally alter the overall immunopathology of TB in this model.

title: Microbiomes of the dust particles collected from the International Space Station and Spacecraft assembly facilities
summary: This study characterized the viable microbial communities in dust samples from the International Space Station (ISS) and compared them to those from Earth-based spacecraft assembly cleanrooms. Using a combination of cultivation and advanced molecular techniques, researchers analyzed the abundance and diversity of microorganisms. The key finding is that the ISS microbiome is distinctly different from the cleanrooms, primarily due to continuous human habitation. The ISS environment was dominated by human skin-associated bacteria from the phylum Actinobacteria, such as Corynebacterium and Propionibacterium. Conversely, Earth-based cleanrooms were dominated by Proteobacteria, which were far less common on the ISS. The research provides strong evidence that human presence is the primary factor shaping the microbial landscape in the ISS closed habitat. Therefore, the study concludes that Earth-based cleanrooms are not an accurate model for the ISS microbial environment. This information is crucial for developing targeted cleaning strategies and ensuring astronaut health on long-duration missions.

title: Draft genome sequences of two Aspergillus fumigatus strains, isolated from the International Space Station
summary: Researchers sequenced the draft genomes of two Aspergillus fumigatus fungal strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). This fungus is an opportunistic pathogen, meaning it can cause disease, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The study was initiated because these ISS-isolated strains were found to be significantly more lethal in a zebrafish model compared to well-known clinical strains from Earth. Furthermore, the space strains demonstrated greater resistance to UV radiation. The primary goal of sequencing their genomes is to investigate the molecular mechanisms that might explain this increased virulence and hardiness. This research is critical for astronaut health, as the human immune system can be weakened during spaceflight. The paper announces the successful assembly of these genomes, providing the technical details of the sequencing process. This genomic data will facilitate future studies into how the space environment affects microbial life and the potential risks to crew members.

title: Characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolates from air and surfaces of the International Space Station.
summary: This research investigates the molecular adaptations of the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus to the unique environment of the International Space Station (ISS). Scientists conducted a proteomic characterization, comparing two fungal strains isolated from the ISS with two standard clinical isolates from Earth. The study revealed that the ISS strains had an increased abundance of specific proteins compared to their terrestrial counterparts. These proteins are primarily involved in stress responses, carbohydrate metabolism, and the production of secondary metabolites and toxins. Notably, proteins related to oxidative stress, the toxin Asp-hemolysin, and the trypacidin biosynthetic pathway were significantly more abundant in the space-faring fungi. These findings suggest that A. fumigatus undergoes molecular changes to adapt to conditions like enhanced radiation, microgravity, and low nutrients. This research provides the first proteomic insight into how filamentous fungi respond to the space environment, which is critical for understanding potential risks to astronaut health on long-duration missions.

title: Draft genome sequences of biosafety level 2 opportunistic pathogens isolated from the environmental surfaces of the International Space Station.
summary: This research presents the draft genome sequences of 20 opportunistic bacterial pathogens isolated from various environmental surfaces on the International Space Station (ISS). The study, part of an ongoing Microbial Observatory experiment, identified several biosafety level 2 (BSL-2) species, including Acinetobacter pittii, Enterobacter sp., and various Staphylococcus species. Staphylococcus aureus was found to be the most prevalent microorganism across all sampled locations. Several of the isolated strains exhibited resistance to common antibiotics such as penicillin, erythromycin, and rifampin. The primary purpose of generating these genomic sequences is to create a foundational dataset for future research. This data will allow for comparative analyses between the ISS strains and their Earth-based counterparts. Ultimately, these comparisons will help scientists understand how the unique microgravity environment influences the pathogenicity and virulence of these microorganisms.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Several Fungal Strains Selected for Exposure to Microgravity at the International Space Station.
summary: This paper presents the draft whole-genome sequences for eight different fungal strains. These specific fungi were selected for a future experiment to study their response to microgravity on the International Space Station (ISS). Many of the chosen strains, such as Aureobasidium pullulans and Cladosporium sphaerospermum, were originally isolated from the Chernobyl nuclear power plant. The paper details the known biotechnological potential of each fungus, including their ability to produce valuable bioactive compounds like the cholesterol-lowering drug lovastatin, bioinsecticides, and various antitumor or antifungal agents. The primary goal of this research was to establish a genomic baseline for these organisms. This genetic information will be crucial for future analysis. It will help researchers understand the molecular mechanisms behind any observed production of novel compounds when these fungi are exposed to the space environment.

title: Human presence impacts fungal diversity of inflated lunar/Mars analog habitat.
summary: This research examines how human presence alters the fungal community, or mycobiome, within a simulated closed space habitat known as the Inflatable Lunar/Mars Analog Habitat (ILMAH). Over a 30-day human occupation, scientists collected and analyzed surface samples using both traditional cultivation and modern DNA sequencing techniques. The study aimed to characterize the changes and succession of fungal species, which is crucial for astronaut health and habitat integrity. Key findings show that while the overall quantity of cultivable fungi decreased over time, the diversity of viable fungal species significantly increased. The fungal community structure was distinctly different on day 20 compared to other time points. Certain fungal genera, including Epiccocum, Alternaria, and Cryptococcus, showed a notable increase in abundance during the occupation period. The results underscore the importance of monitoring and managing the microbial environment in closed systems for future long-duration space missions.

title: Microbial Characteristics of ISS Environmental Surfaces
summary: This research analyzes the functional characteristics of microbes collected over several years from the International Space Station's (ISS) potable water system. Moving beyond simple genetic identification, the study focused on key phenotypes like antibiotic resistance, metabolism, and biofilm formation to understand potential risks to astronaut health and life-support systems. The analysis revealed that many of the isolated microbes, particularly Burkholderia and Ralstonia species, were resistant to multiple drugs and were strong biofilm formers. A significant finding was the discovery of hemolytic activity in some Burkholderia isolates, indicating a potential health risk for astronauts who may have compromised immune systems. The study also observed that interactions between different microbial species depended on their year of isolation, suggesting that the microbial community is adapting and evolving over time within the unique, closed environment of the ISS. These results highlight the importance of functional analysis for microbial risk assessment in isolated habitats like the ISS and have implications for water systems on Earth.

title: Draft Genome Sequences from a Novel Clade of Bacillus cereus Sensu Lato Strains, Isolated from the International Space Station.
summary: This research paper announces the draft genome sequences of six Bacillus strains isolated from various modules of the International Space Station (ISS). The strains, collected from the Japanese, U.S., and Russian segments, belong to the Bacillus cereus sensu lato group. Using Illumina MiSeq and PacBio sequencing technologies, researchers assembled and analyzed the bacterial genomes. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all six isolates have a very high degree of genetic similarity to each other. Due to their close genomic relationship to the pathogenic B. anthracis, the strains were specifically examined for virulence factors. The study found no evidence of the signature elements or plasmids that cause pathogenicity in B. anthracis. The collective genomic evidence supports the conclusion that these six ISS isolates represent a novel, non-pathogenic Bacillus species.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Acinetobacter and Bacillus Strains Isolated from Spacecraft-Associated Surfaces
summary: This research paper announces the draft genome sequences for four resilient bacterial strains isolated from spacecraft surfaces and their assembly clean rooms. The study focuses on two Bacillus species (B. horneckiae, B. nealsonii) and two Acinetobacter species (A. radioresistens, A. proteolyticus). These microbes are notable for their heightened resistance to environmental stressors relevant to space exploration, including UV radiation, hydrogen peroxide, and desiccation. The primary achievement of the study was the successful sequencing of their genomes, with reported sizes ranging from approximately 3.2 to 5.5 million base pairs. Analysis of the genomic data revealed specific genes that likely contribute to their hardiness. These include genes associated with dormancy, sporulation, and DNA repair in the Bacillus strains. The Acinetobacter strains were found to possess genes for stress responses, oxidative stress protection, and resistance to heavy metals. This genomic information provides a crucial foundation for understanding the genetic mechanisms that enable microbial survival in the extreme and highly sanitized environments associated with space missions.

title: KatharoSeq enables high-throughput microbiome analysis from low-biomass samples
summary: Researchers developed a new high-throughput protocol named KatharoSeq to accurately analyze microbial communities in low-biomass environments, which are notoriously difficult to study due to contamination. This new method combines laboratory and bioinformatic techniques to reliably detect true microbial signals from samples containing as few as 50 to 500 cells. KatharoSeq is significantly faster than traditional single-tube methods and incorporates controls to ensure data quality. To demonstrate its effectiveness, the protocol was applied to three distinct environments: a spacecraft assembly facility (SAF), a hospital's neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), and an abalone-rearing facility. In the SAF, the study identified specific microbes like *Acinetobacter lwoffii* and linked their presence to human foot traffic. The method also successfully distinguished unique microbiomes in the NICU and the abalone facility, relating them to patient disease and the marine environment, respectively. These findings establish KatharoSeq as a feasible and valuable tool for large-scale metagenomic studies in low-biomass settings.

title: Draft genome sequence of a clinical isolate of Fusarium fujikuroi isolated from a male patient with acute myeloid leukemia.
summary: This paper announces the draft whole-genome sequence of Fusarium fujikuroi, specifically strain COH1152. The fungus was isolated from a 68-year-old male patient with acute myeloid leukemia undergoing chemotherapy. While primarily known as a devastating plant pathogen, this research highlights Fusarium's increasing recognition as an opportunistic human pathogen, causing infections known as fusariosis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. The patient developed invasive hyphal elements in a skin lesion, and the fungus was cultured from both blood and tissue samples. The genome was sequenced using an Illumina HiSeq platform, resulting in a 48 Mb assembly. The study also notes the sequencing of another isolate, COH1141, which was identified as a laboratory contaminant of Aspergillus niger. The genomic data for both isolates has been deposited in public databases, including NASA GeneLab, for further research.

title: Draft Genome Sequence of Solibacillus kalamii, Isolated from an Air Filter Aboard the International Space Station
summary: Researchers report the draft genome sequence of a novel bacterium, Solibacillus kalamii, discovered on a high-energy particulate arrestance (HEPA) air filter from the International Space Station (ISS). The filter was in service aboard the ISS for 40 months before being returned to Earth for molecular analysis. The draft genome of this bacterial strain, ISSFR-015, is approximately 3.8 million base pairs in length. Analysis of the genome provides significant insight into the bacterium's ability to survive in extreme environments. The sequence revealed putative genes associated with resistance to various stressors, including oxidative stress, heavy metals like copper and arsenic, and vancomycin. These genetic characteristics suggest that S. kalamii is highly resilient and well-adapted to the harsh conditions of the ISS. Its survival is likely aided by these genes, which help it withstand both the spacecraft environment and rigorous cleaning procedures.

title: Detection of antimicrobial resistance genes associated with the International Space Station environmental surfaces
summary: This research analyzes the microbial communities found on various surfaces inside the International Space Station (ISS) over a 14-month period, building upon the previous Microbial Tracking-1 study. Using shotgun metagenomics and culturing methods, scientists identified the types of bacteria and fungi present, tracked how they changed over time, and cataloged their antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes. The study found that the ISS microbiome is dominated by human-associated microbes, particularly Staphylococcus bacteria and Malassezia fungi from skin. While the microbial populations changed significantly over time, likely influenced by different astronaut crews, there were no notable differences between the eight locations sampled. This suggests microbes are distributed evenly throughout the sealed environment. In contrast to the changing microbial community, the profile of AMR genes was remarkably stable over a five-year period. Researchers identified 29 AMR genes, with resistance to macrolide/lincosamide/streptogramin being the most widespread. This data provides a detailed snapshot of the ISS's living environment, which can help develop policies to protect astronaut health on future long-duration space missions.

title: Draft genome sequences of two Fusarium oxysporum isolates cultured from infected Zinnia hybrida plants grown on the International Space Station.
summary: This research presents the draft whole-genome sequences of two fungal isolates, Fusarium oxysporum, which infected Zinnia hybrida plants grown on the International Space Station (ISS). The fungi, which caused a rot disease in the plants during the "Veggie" project, were cultured from the plant's leaf and root. Genome sequencing and assembly were performed for both isolates. Comparative analysis revealed that these ISS-grown fungal strains are most closely related to an F. oxysporum isolate cultured in the aftermath of the Chernobyl disaster. Furthermore, both the ISS and Chernobyl strains showed high similarity to a clinical strain isolated from a human patient suffering from fusariosis. The findings suggest that comparing these genomes could reveal genetic traits, such as radiation resistance, that allow organisms to thrive in extreme environments.

title: Characterization of Aspergillus niger Isolated from the International Space Station
summary: This research characterizes a strain of the fungus Aspergillus niger isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and compares it to a standard lab strain. The study found that the ISS isolate produces significantly higher levels of several therapeutically relevant secondary metabolites. Most notably, production of the antioxidant pyranonigrin A was increased by 6000% in the space-faring fungus. Researchers successfully identified the biosynthetic gene cluster responsible for creating pyranonigrin A, discovering the involvement of a previously undescribed gene, pyrE. They also identified genetic variants in the ISS strain, including mutations in gene promoter regions, that may be responsible for this enhanced production. Furthermore, the study demonstrated that pyranonigrin A serves as a UV resistance agent for the fungus. These findings provide insight into how fungi may adapt to the stressful environment of space.

title: Multi-drug resistant Enterobacter bugandensis species isolated from the International Space Station and comparative genomic analyses with human pathogenic strains
summary: This research analyzes five strains of the bacterium Enterobacter bugandensis isolated from two locations on the International Space Station (ISS). Scientists conducted whole-genome sequencing and compared the ISS strains to three clinical, pathogenic strains found on Earth. The analysis revealed that the space station bacteria were genetically similar to the disease-causing strains from terrestrial hospitals. Notably, the ISS strains possess 112 genes associated with virulence, disease, and defense. The study also identified numerous genes responsible for resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds, confirming them as multi-drug resistant (MDR). A key finding was the presence of a multiple antibiotic resistance (MAR) operon, a genetic system that can regulate over 60 genes, including drug efflux pumps. The paper concludes that, given their MDR nature and a high predicted probability of pathogenicity, these bacteria pose a significant health risk for astronauts on future missions. Further in-vivo research is recommended to determine how microgravity affects their disease-causing capabilities.

title: Succession and persistence of microbial communities and antimicrobial resistance genes associated with International Space Station environmental surfaces
summary: This text is a correction to a 2018 research paper about microbial communities on the environmental surfaces of the International Space Station (ISS). The authors clarify the correct number of high-quality reads before and after normalization. They confirm that this numerical error did not affect the study's conclusions on taxonomic diversity. The text concludes with the authors' apology for the mistake.

title: International Space Station conditions alter genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics in Aspergillus nidulans.
summary: This research provides the first comprehensive analysis of how the fungus Aspergillus nidulans is affected by the conditions aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Scientists grew a wild-type and three mutant strains of the fungus in space and compared their genomic, proteomic, and metabolic profiles to ground-based controls. The study revealed that the space environment induced specific genetic mutations in the fungus, including changes to genes involved in RNA activity and, in one mutant strain, the loss of a stop codon for a key regulatory gene. Furthermore, significant alterations were observed in protein expression, particularly for proteins related to stress response and metabolism. The production of secondary metabolites was also impacted, with a decrease in certain compounds in the wild-type and an increase in others in mutant strains. These findings demonstrate that A. nidulans undergoes distinct molecular adaptations to survive in space. The data provides valuable insights into fungal biology in spacecraft, which is important for crew health and potential space-based biotechnology.

title: Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from air and surfaces of the International Space Station.
summary: This research provides a proteomic analysis of the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus, specifically studying two strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). The study compared the protein profiles of these space-faring strains against two standard, earth-based clinical isolates to understand molecular adaptations to the unique space environment. Key findings reveal significant differences in the proteomes of the ISS strains. Specifically, proteins associated with stress responses, carbohydrate metabolism, and secondary metabolism were found in higher abundance in the space isolates. This includes proteins involved in oxidative stress response, ethanol fermentation, and the biosynthesis of toxins like trypacidin and Asp-hemolysin. These molecular changes suggest that A. fumigatus adapts to the stressors of space, such as microgravity and enhanced radiation. The study concludes that these adaptations could be linked to the previously observed increased virulence of these strains, highlighting the importance of understanding microbial behavior for astronaut health during long-term space missions.

title: Genomic Characterization and Virulence Potential of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from the International Space Station
summary: This research is the first to isolate and genomically characterize the fungus Fusarium oxysporum from a built environment in space. Two strains, ISS-F3 and ISS-F4, were cultured from a dining table on the International Space Station (ISS). Genomic analysis revealed these two strains are nearly identical to each other but are genetically distinct from 65 known terrestrial strains. The study found that while the ISS strains are unlikely to be plant pathogens, they may produce novel secondary metabolites. A significant finding was that the strains demonstrated virulence in an immunocompromised animal model (C. elegans). This suggests they could act as opportunistic pathogens in animals, including humans. The results highlight potential health risks for immunocompromised astronauts on long-duration missions and the need for further study.

title: Characterization of the total and viable bacterial and fungal communities associated with the International Space Station surfaces.
summary: This study comprehensively characterized the bacterial and fungal communities living on surfaces inside the International Space Station (ISS). Researchers collected samples from eight distinct locations over a 14-month period across three missions. The analysis combined traditional culturing with modern molecular techniques, such as DNA sequencing, to identify a broader range of microbes than previously possible. A specific chemical treatment, propidium monoazide (PMA), was used to distinguish between intact, viable microbes and the total microbial DNA present, which includes dead cells. The results revealed a diverse microbial population dominated by organisms associated with the human microbiome, including potential opportunistic pathogens. While the bacterial community composition changed over time, it remained consistent across different locations. In contrast, the fungal community was stable over both time and location. This research provides the first detailed catalog of viable microbes in a closed space environment, crucial for developing safety measures and protecting astronaut health on future long-duration missions.

title: Proteomic and Metabolomic Characteristics of Extremophilic Fungi Under Simulated Mars Conditions.
summary: This research is the first to investigate the survival of fungal conidia monolayers under simulated Mars conditions (SMC). The study tested strains of extremophilic fungi isolated from the Chernobyl nuclear accident site and the International Space Station (ISS). Survival was found to be strain-dependent, with two specific strains, Aspergillus fumigatus (ISS-isolated) and Cladosporium cladosporioides (Chernobyl-isolated), surviving a 30-minute exposure to SMC. A subsequent molecular analysis was performed on these survivors to understand their adaptation mechanisms. While no significant changes were observed in the fungi's metabolome, their proteomes showed distinct alterations. The ISS strain up-regulated proteins involved in ribosome biogenesis and translation. Conversely, the Chernobyl strain mostly down-regulated proteins in these same categories, suggesting different survival strategies. Additionally, the ISS strain that survived SMC exposure exhibited enhanced resistance to UV-C radiation upon re-exposure.

title: MetaMiner: A Scalable Peptidogenomics Approach for Discovery of Ribosomal Peptide Natural Products with Blind Modifications from Microbial Communities
summary: This research introduces MetaMiner, a new software tool designed for the large-scale discovery of ribosomally synthesized and post-translationally modified peptides (RiPPs) from microbial communities. RiPPs are an important source of bioactive compounds like antibiotics, but their discovery has been hindered by methods that cannot handle large datasets or unknown chemical modifications. MetaMiner addresses these limitations by integrating genome mining with computational mass spectrometry, enabling a fast, automated search that can identify peptides with previously unknown modifications. The software was tested by searching millions of mass spectra against eight genomic and metagenomic datasets. This analysis resulted in the identification of 38 RiPPs, including 31 known compounds and seven completely new ones. Significantly, these discoveries spanned diverse environments, from the human and lichen microbiomes to micro-organisms isolated from the International Space Station. The success of MetaMiner demonstrates a scalable approach to uncovering the vast, untapped potential of microbial natural products.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Sphingomonas Species Associated with the International Space Station
summary: This research paper announces the successful assembly of draft genome sequences for three strains of Sphingomonas bacteria isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). The identified strains are two Sphingomonas sanguinis and one Sphingomonas paucimobilis. These bacteria are known for diverse characteristics, including pollutant degradation, biofilm formation, and in some cases, acting as opportunistic pathogens. The primary purpose of sequencing these genomes is to create a foundational dataset for future comparative studies. By comparing the genomes of the ISS strains to their Earth-based counterparts, scientists aim to understand the genetic adaptations and changes that occur in response to spaceflight conditions. The key goal is to investigate the influence of microgravity and elevated radiation on the bacteria's potential to produce bioactive compounds and other significant traits. The complete genomic data has been deposited in public databases to facilitate further research in the field of space biology.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Tremellomycetes Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
summary: Researchers isolated six strains of eukaryotic microbes from the International Space Station (ISS) and sequenced their draft genomes. These fungal strains belong to the class Tremellomycetes, specifically the genera Naganishia and Papiliotrema. This work is part of a larger microbial monitoring experiment aboard the ISS. The study is significant because some related fungal species are known to be opportunistic human pathogens, and understanding their characteristics in space is crucial. By assembling these draft genomes, scientists have created a foundational genetic resource for future analysis. The ultimate goal is to use this sequence data to understand how microgravity might influence the microbes' potential to cause disease. Further characterization will help identify genetic factors related to pathogenicity, allowing for comparison with Earth-based counterparts. This report provides the technical details of the genome assemblies, paving the way for deeper insights into microbial survival and adaptation in space environments.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Rhodotorula mucilaginosa Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
summary: This research paper announces the successful generation of whole-genome sequences for 28 strains of the yeast Rhodotorula mucilaginosa, which were isolated from surfaces inside the International Space Station (ISS). R. mucilaginosa is the most common yeast found on the ISS and is also classified as an emerging human pathogen. The study emphasizes the importance of understanding this yeast in the context of spaceflight, as it can form biofilms that may colonize and damage life support systems. Furthermore, the harsh conditions of the ISS, including microgravity and radiation, have been shown to enhance biofilm formation and antimicrobial resistance in some microbes. By sequencing these genomes, researchers can now identify specific genes responsible for these traits. This genomic data is critical for developing countermeasures to eradicate this potential threat to astronaut health and mission equipment. The resulting whole-genome sequences have been made publicly available for further scientific investigation.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Enterobacteriales Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
summary: Researchers generated and analyzed the whole-genome sequences of 26 bacterial strains isolated from various surfaces on the International Space Station (ISS). The strains were identified as belonging to the order Enterobacteriales, which includes species known to be pathogenic to humans. Specific bacteria identified were Pantoea brenneri, Pantoea agglomerans, Kalamiella piersonii, and Enterobacter bugandensis, some of which are associated with human infections and multi-drug resistance on Earth. This research is important because astronauts can be immunocompromised during long-duration space missions, increasing their susceptibility to infection. These bacteria demonstrate an ability to adapt to extreme environments like microgravity and radiation, allowing them to persist on the ISS. By characterizing their genomes, scientists aim to understand the genetic basis for potential pathogenicity. This knowledge could help in developing countermeasures to mitigate health risks for astronauts and ensure crew safety.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Lactobacillales Isolated from the International Space Station
summary: Researchers isolated nineteen bacterial strains from the order Lactobacillales on the International Space Station (ISS) and a commercial resupply vehicle. The primary objective was to generate whole-genome sequences (WGS) for these isolates to better understand them. This genomic analysis is crucial for characterizing these potentially pathogenic bacteria, which may have adapted to the extreme conditions of the space environment. The identified species include Enterococcus faecalis, Enterococcus faecium, and Aerococcus urinaeequi. This research is important for astronaut health, as long-duration spaceflight can compromise the immune system, increasing susceptibility to infection. The Enterococcus species are known to cause hospital-acquired infections and exhibit antibiotic resistance, while the Aerococcus strain has also been reported as vancomycin-resistant. Ultimately, sequencing these genomes provides foundational data to identify virulence factors and develop countermeasures to mitigate microbial risks during space missions.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Klebsiella Species Isolated from the International Space Station
summary: Researchers isolated ten bacterial strains from four different locations on the environmental surfaces of the International Space Station (ISS). This genomic data is intended to enable future comparative studies between the ISS strains and their terrestrial counterparts. Such analysis will provide critical insights into how these bacteria adapt to the unique environment of space.

Understanding these microbes could prevent the forward contamination of other planets. The generated genomic data is now publicly available for further analysis. This will help scientists understand the roles these bacteria play in closed space environments and explore their potential for future biotechnological applications.

title: Assessing the risk of transfer of microorganisms at the International Space Station due to cargo delivery by commercial resupply vehicles
summary: This study investigates the risk of microbial contamination transferred from commercial resupply vehicles (CRVs) to the International Space Station (ISS). Researchers analyzed microbial samples from the internal surfaces and ground support equipment of three CRV missions prior to their launch. Using molecular and cultivation techniques, they compared the microbial communities, or microbiomes, of the CRVs with existing data from the ISS. A key finding was that the internal surfaces of the vehicles were extremely clean, harboring significantly fewer microbes than the external ground support equipment. The study also noted that later CRV missions were cleaner than the first one sampled, indicating improving and effective cleaning procedures. Metagenome sequencing revealed that the microbial population on the CRVs was distinctly different from the ISS microbiome. The researchers concluded that the CRV microbiomes contribute a negligible amount to the overall microbial environment of the ISS. These results demonstrate that current cleaning protocols are highly effective in preventing forward contamination, which is crucial for planetary protection on future interplanetary missions.

title: Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov., isolated from the International Space Station
summary: Researchers isolated four bacterial strains belonging to the Methylobacteriaceae family from various locations on the International Space Station (ISS) across two missions. Comprehensive analysis identified one strain as Methylorubrum rhodesianum, a known species. However, the other three strains were found to be genetically identical to each other but distinct from any previously cataloged bacteria. Using polyphasic taxonomic methods, which combine genomic, phenotypic, and chemical data, the scientists confirmed the novelty of these strains. Whole-genome sequencing showed that their average nucleotide identity (ANI) and digital DNA-DNA hybridization (dDDH) values were below the established thresholds for classifying them within any existing species, with Methylobacterium indicum being their closest relative. Phenotypically, these Gram-negative, rod-shaped bacteria grow optimally at 25-30°C. Based on the extensive evidence, the researchers concluded that these three strains represent a new species. They proposed the name Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov. for this novel bacterium discovered in the unique, closed environment of the ISS.
